title: The fountain of brilliance
review:
Greetings all,

So the order of the day is a story that transcends intertwining time lines, and by Jove does this film do it in such accomplished manner. If that wasn't enough, each separate story may be portrayed in a nonlinear fashion, much to my delight, as I do love that which is not run-of-the-mill.

When it commences one may question the ambiguity/vagueness of the three short stories, as little explanation is provided for each. But with the progression of the film will come an admiration for this style, which will endear the viewer no end to the six main characters, all of whom are played wonderfully by Hugh Jackman and Rachel Weisz respectively.

Complemented further are these scenes with their beautiful transitions through general motifs that overlie each set piece, and gradually build on each character's history. Another standout aspect for me.

Clint Mansell does a good a job as ever, matching the tone of each scene with perfection, leading to a greater immersion in the subject matter. A very memorable score indeed.

My only slight foible would be that for the general viewer this may prove a little too complex, if not given enough of a chance. And some of the residing biblical connotations may be out of favour for some.

This film is more than just spectacle, it delivers on so many levels. I must say with great confidence that this is perhaps Jackman's career-defining role. And although I don't find Aronofsky to be a consistent high performer, I'll say without a doubt that The Fountain is my favourite film of his. I cannot advise watching this enough.

title: A fantastic Sci-Fi movie...
review:
"The Fountain" is a Sci-Fi movie which has to do with three parallel stories, the first is in the past, the second in the present and the third in the future. These three stories are in contact because the actors are also connected with them.

I liked this movie because it has plenty of suspense and passion and I believe that these two feelings are in the most out in this movie and make it unique. I also liked this movie because of the interpretations of Hugh Jackman who is really outstanding and Rachel Weisz who is also made a really nice interpretation.

Finally I have to tell you that I recommend this movie and I believe that you will really love it if you are a fan of parallel story movies.

title: Aronofsky's baby - loved but frustratingly misguided
review:
I stumbled across my notes for this a couple of days ago and finally managed to allocate the time to write up a review. I saw this twice when it came out in 2006, not much has changed from then, as I remember the movie quite vividly still. Aronofsky had a real passion for this project and was desperately searching for funding for almost 10 years. I can imagine that the story must have changed in his mind multiple times as he matured as a writer/director during the beginning of the new millennium.

Considering the circumstances and the fact that he had to cut a lot of material because of a "low budget" production, it's understandable that the movie did not completely work for me. It was frustrating because,on paper, it was all there: 1. A multi-layered parallel/reverse narrative spanning across time, involving 3 stories of faith, fear, love, and a recollection that "finishes" them. 2. A number of metaphors-tree as life, death as rebirth, fear as obsession etc... 3. Inherent passionate love stories for the project and between Darren and Rachel coming from the outer reality. One of which, I assume was as equally obsessive as Dr.Creo's pursuit. I believe this was unintended and only in hindsight.

Unfortunately, however, these were not connected with each other. The passion and love that permeate the whole project had to be the core that everything else was built around. Instead, the narrative devices and other themes get in the way, obscuring our vision of the couple making love.

I recommend seeing this, if solely based on the passion you will feel. You are likely to be inspired yet somewhat frustrated. Be careful with some of the ideas that Aronofsky planted, the movie seems to be celebrated as a "cult" classic.

4/5 - Worth a watch

title: Thank you for bringing the most precious spiritual principles to a Hollywood movie
review:
For me the movie is perfect and one of the most successful (if not the most) in bringing spiritual teachings to the screen.

The message is so subtle as special and compassionate; that you don't need to cling to "this" life or to "that person, because you don't need "to" love someone, but just to let this limited conscience dissolves, so you can become compassion and love and shines upon everyone.

Dissolution - the letting go of self - that's what the movie is about.

So, the protagonist's quest; to stop death, changes to a worth quest - to stop suffering, and everything just begins to flow again.

Thanks Darren for this rare gem.

title: Mesmerizing!
review:
This is an exquisitely beautiful, mesmerizing movie that just gets better every time I see it. One of those rare films transcend "movie" and are best described as an "experience".

Some viewers apparently found it difficult to absorb, to me it was much the opposite, drawing me in and immersing me in the storytelling and hypnotic soundtrack. Sadly, it seems to have gone over the head of most critics.

Smartly bridging between spirituality and science fiction without getting caught in the silliness of fantasy or trappings of religion, the tone is always somber and the non-digital, organic special effects are appropriately warm, earthy, and subdued.

The Kronos Quartet soundtrack is equally masterful, and the Clint Mansell piano solo through the end credits - accompanied by a stylized depiction of the universe forming after the big bang - is nothing short of ethereal.

It was apparently conceived as a big-budget epic before the studios axed the project. Aronofsky retooled it into an intimate, solemn masterpiece and it is now utterly impossible to imagine it in any other form.

This is definitely not a movie for everyone, but if it's up your alley, it may haunt you for life.

title: Not for everyone
review:
As this site demonstrates The Fountain is a movie people either love or hate, although personally I think most people are left pretty confused by it, whether they liked it or not. It really is a movie you should watch at least twice and also have a good think about between the viewings. The visuals are very impressive in all the three parts of the story being told; the main part which features Tom/Jackman trying to invent a cure for his dying wife, Izzi/ Rachel Weisz; a renaissance part which features him as a conquistador searching for the Fountain of Youth on behalf of her as the Spanish Queen, which is the novel Izzi is writing, perhaps intentionally as an allegory of their "real" struggle; and a third part which is possibly his subconscious interacting with some form of tree of life, although various New Age/religious interpretations are, I'm sure, plausible as well. Some striking cinematography at least makes sure The Fountain doesn't look like any other movie. Overlaying this is some very evocative music by Kurt Mansell, and although I am usually pretty iffy about movie music in general as a cheap way to manipulate an audience more than something you specifically need it works great here. Tired as I am of this American movie convention, I never got my customary annoyed thoughts of "where the hell is the 60 piece orchestra seated in this medieval battle and had the cello even been invented yet?" moments while watching The Fountain. Perhaps it helps if you like the music though, which I generally don't in movies. When it comes to the plot there really isn't much of one, and what I wrote above is basically all there really is to it externally. However it is full of depth as well, and invites symbolic and allegorical interpretations. Naturally this is the part of it that won't appeal to everyone though, since most people generally prefer simple, linear narratives to exposition and symbolism. Some people will dismiss it because of this and think it's pretentious, which perhaps it is. But then it's arrogant in my view to insist that movies must be made in a specific way, with simple narratives and no depth to the viewing experience of any kind. Who's to say there needs to be linearity or even real people in movies at all? Why not archetypes and representations of time and space telling something different instead?

Not saying they should be but for people who like it simple and "unpretentious" there are about a billion other movies to watch.

title: The Fountain takes us on a breathtaking journey to the only eternal state in life - DEATH
review:
Browsing through several reviews... i could never get a decisive feel of the movie...and the same remains true after seeing the movie.

The movie's screenplay is an absolute masterpiece and the script which had 3 parallel plays could've never held together without the monumental performance delivered by Hugh Jackman... Who quests for eternity in his love... in 3 different phases of time.The movie at the beginning might appear as yet another slow paced sci-fi... but the screenplay is actually moving in knots... and yet u never fail to miss even a single piece of emotion,love and substance of the movie.

Rachel Weisz who plays the love of his life, has a serene screen presence which glides the story through the different periods of the quest without even a single piece of rough patch in the script's regular transition between the different periods.The music invents the movie to great heights as you cant help but to feel the love as it oscillates between life and death.

The concept was scintillating, spiritual and most of all different and will have every viewer's eyes and minds glued to it.The concept wins in arriving at a regular note of "DEATH BEING THE GATEWAY OF CREATION" in an entirely different manner and the climax voices different views all at once which aids the film with a strong,sound finish.This movie is certain to remain permanent in my collection and deserves the same on yours too.....

title: Absolutely stupendous.
review:
This is in my top ten favourite films, ever! It is like a moving work of art. The visuals are stunning, breathtaking. It will make your heart soar and it will break your heart. You will want to watch this movie when you need to be uplifted or when you need a good cry.

I was mesmerized and enthralled throughout the entire film. Although the concept of parallel realities/time travel in science fiction/fantasy has been done to death, this is truly unique. I cannot think of any other film in this genre that comes close to it.

This is a film I will be watching over and over-- can't get enough of it.

title: Darren Aronofsky is great at every genre!
review:
With Requiem for a Dream he made maybe the best drug-drama movie.

With Pi he succeeded a mathematical thriller.

With Black Swan he traveled us in the darkest levels off the human mind. With The Fountain he made a really beautiful Science Fiction Movie which has the main themes of philosophy: life, death, time&space.

The movie is separated in three story set in three different time.Each story tells something to the next one and at the final off the movie we will have the puzzle complete.The main line off the puzzle is the love between Tomas and Isabel. Tomas would give everything to save Isabel even if that means to defeat death.He calls it a disease and he wants to find it's cure.

The roles are played greatly by Hugh Jackman and Rachel Weisz.

title: The right way to be immortal !
review:
Sometimes a movie is so good to the extent of not knowing how to write about it. (The Fountain) has many reasons to be one. But I think 2 pieces of info can provide an intro to speak easily about its beauty. The first is that its writer / director (Darren Aronofsky) loves classic movies. And the second is that he, as a teenager, spent time doing graffiti art.

Now this man could evoke a meaning about the importance of faith and accepting death as a step in life. It's where the awful clinging to life mirrors a wrong understanding of love. So lastly, thinking that he overcame death and reached immortality, the lead invented none other than a way to distance himself from his love for longer time. Hence he should surrender to death as fate that will re-gather him with his love; namely believe in the divine law. Clearly meanings like these have been lost in the Hollywood movies lately. You must remind the old classic ones, especially when it comes to faith. Then, the artistic vision of (Aronofsky). Oh my god. He could make a very sophisticated image yet in a lovely way. Aside from being good looking movie, it managed to be a book of signs, dealing with life, death, and love by symbolic forms, as if it makes its own artistic dictionary.

The chromatic personality of the film was precise. The brown and black for most of the events, as long as the desire for immortality is on, a dark desire for that matter. The golden yellow for moments like the drug's discovery; since it mirrors – in the film's conscience – a sick thirst to delaying death but ending it. The too glaring white for the true love or going to death. See also how the scenes of the husband and his dying wife are natural yet in a black frame or depth. Then, the green triumphs eventually, when the Spanish knight sees the fountain for the first time, however to assure that the immortality in life may be given for things, not humans (the nightmarish moment of the plants grow out of his body, burying him as the answer to his eternity).

While not having a huge budget in his hands, (Aronofsky), in a way that dazzled me personally, didn't use any CGI. Instead, he chose to do the special effects by using micro-photography of chemical reactions on tiny petri dishes. A very old way, but it worked, being no less than any more costly way. And most of all it didn't look fake, be hyped up, or feel made for itself.

The performance is sensitive and truthful. A scene like the one of the bath fascinated me indeed. Makes you somehow hate the action and comic movies that worn out stars, like (Hugh Jackman), (Rachel Weisz) or else, to a degree where true characters and feelings become rare to find, and the actor, inside of such stars, fades out !

The problem remains in the script's third act. It's confused. For instance, how come that the lead is the last man on earth ? He, one way or another, found a drug to lesson the ageing, however why there isn't any other human alive with him ? How nobody drank it but him since it must have been gone public ? Another, more dangerous, matter which is the 3 stories' meeting point. The line between the past's Spanish knight and the present's doctor was a bit blurred. Some would be pushed to think that they're one, not a fictional character / the knight in a book which the factual lead / the doctor completes. Anyway, something was rushed about that third.

By watching many of (Darren Aronofsky)'s works, I believe he has an obsession. Nearly all of his films are bout the human lust. The addiction, of drug and fame, in (Requiem for a Dream – 2000). The desire of being immortal in (The Fountain – 2006). And the complete opposite, yet the same extreme, in (Black Swan – 2010) where the lust is terribly suppressed. For him lust, without balance or real love, is a fertile source of horror. And the original maker of hell is the human self.

(Aronofsky) seems not interested in Hollywood blockbusters, so he directed only 5 movies in 12 years. While being not so smart choice from his side, which may change soon, he had a great opportunity to be interesting, different and unique with a few movies, I see that (The Fountain) is their most perfect yet, whether intellectually or visually.

An enjoyable thought-provoking film, with maybe the greatest message of them all. How many times you could say that about a film ? In a word : immortality can be won by work like this.

title: Perfect
review: It is rare to find a movie so meaningful, interesting and beautiful altogether. The music is perfect. It really can give some idea of the reincarnation, karma and eternity - the process that all we are involved in this world. Although it does not go far than this, to the questions as "Is there anything beyond karma, and incarnation", and "what is it?",or "How to go there". The conclusion that the eternal life in this world is impossible, or even if it becomes almost possible is meaningless, is another marvellous insight. The movie does not give the way but it can help for certain realizations for the real seekers. Serious movie that is a must to see. The real average rating should be over 8.

title: Wonderfully deep and meaningful Film
review:
A beautiful film that touches on the key elements of Life that we must all one day face and endure ... Love, Life, Death and the loss of those who are closest to our hearts. I wont go into detail as I don't want to spoil the story for those who are yet to watch the film in its splendor.

HOWEVER, I will warn you that it takes a certain type of viewer to appreciate this film as the mixed reviews will show. Yes there are 3 story lines that run simultaneously throughout the film, there are many scenes that require interpretation so if you enjoy the drone of a 'Die Hard' style film with repetitive gunfire and car chases then this is not the right choice for you. You will get lost, bored and end up writing reviews about how pretentious this film is.

But for those who can appreciate the beauty of this film, it will stay long in your memory and you'll end up promoting it to as many people as you can :)

title: Underrated Success:
review:
Not only is "The Fountain" as visually stunning as it is conceptually innovative, Hugh Jackman isn't half-bad as a Spanish-Conquistador/Doctor/Futuristic-Cosmonaut protagonist; Rachel Weisz as Queen Isabella, well...

... I'll let you decide that one.

This isn't the kind of film for typical movie-goers, nor is it something fully appreciable in a single sitting. You're not going to 'get it' the first time: no-one does. And I think it's open to interpretation. Whatever you might garner from its bland synopsis - about 'The Tree of Life' as its paramount feature - are limiting and obvious. Envisage instead The Tree as a sort of underpinning axle to which three parallel stories - involving a Spanish Conquistador, a Contemporary Physician and a Spiritualistic Cosmonaut - intertwine.

Whatever can be said about The Fountain's structure remains debatable; and is probably the reason for anyone's initial confusion. Favouring a non-linear approach, we are torn as to whether the past is in fact the past, and not the (fictional) 'past' of Izzi's book which Tommy frequents; and if the future Tom is in fact the previously mentioned Tommy, whose research into 'immortality' was in fact, perhaps a success. And if you thought that was a mouthful, then this probably isn't a film for you...

It's an eye-opening feature with vast room for exploration and interpretation. Sometimes its capacity for philosophical as well as spiritual conceptions become clouded in contextual obfuscation: the less you know, the less you'll know the film. The Bible is a start, but the subjective references to this are as endless and far-reaching as Eliot's "The Wasteland". You'll only get as much out of this film as you put in. Don't be fooled by any characters' outwardly-appearing shallowness, everyone and everything has a place in this film to great symbolic effect.

I don't really want to tell you definitively, what this film's about - when you're watching it for the first time, (hopefully) open-minded, you'll experience either one of two responses: 1. Epiphany 2. WTF And if you're really lucky, both...

If you like to think while watching a movie, The Fountain is a mental, Olympian-workout.

title: Absolutely Mindblowing
review:
"The Fountain" is a movie like no other. A powerful spiritual and organic voyage into the unknown abstract. This is, by far, one of the most powerful movies I've ever seen in my life.

The movie tells its story very subtly, perhaps in the vein of Kubrick, but a powerful tale about love and death non-the-less. I won't speak more of the plot in fear of spoiling anything, but it is amazing.

The cast did an outstanding job, especially the main actors, bringing these characters into life, making us feel them, believe in them and go through the feelings with them. The love between Tommy and Izzi is palpable. Tommy's sadness is so unnerving and upsetting, it makes the whole trip that much touching.

Visually, the movie is absolutely perfect. Mind blowing eye candy visual effects. A fantastical vision that contrasts itself with the theme that surrounds the movie. So pretty yet so sad. So simple, yet so powerful. Photography is top notch as well, very dark and morbid at times, portraying the scenes perfectly.

The music is hauntingly beautiful. After watching the movie I felt obligated to buy the soundtrack. Clint Mansell, together with the Kronos Quartet and Mogwai, created one of the most stunning and beautiful soundtracks I've ever had the pleasure to listen to. As powerful as the movie, touching, just absolutely beautiful.

I can't really fit this movie into any genre... If you're in for a very visual, touching and powerful drama / sci-fi movie you have got to give this a try!

The way the last few minutes of the movie made me feel, summarize the movie very well: Goosebumps.

Flawless 10 out 10.

title: A masterpiece... thoroughly captivating...
review:
A masterpiece.... a beautiful work of art.... sublime.... in every aspect.... from script to music to composition. They don't make movies like this anymore... this experience was much more than entertainment.

The connection between Mayan history, bible scripture, bioengineering, life and death, eternal love, are excellent.

The beautiful landscapes, motion, and colors are breathtaking.

The script... what can I say??? thoroughly captivating ! I found it to be a truly moving and a spiritual experience.

Very ingenious... the Mayan cherub guarding the tree of life with the flaming sword.... found in central America.... believable when considering the continental drift theory.... it all is very believable.

Then the climactic moments.... the Queen and Izzi on the spaceship... changing characters in an instant... "Together we will live forever"... with a tear.... sublime.

And his soft whispers to the Tree of Life and Izzi, "Everything will be alright"... totally romantic.

The way this movie was made, its variance to time sequence, the script and that beautiful... beautiful music... make it a masterpiece.

That is my opinion.

A masterpiece.

title: Doesn't make a ton of sense, but I admire the ambition,
review:
Darren Arronofsky is a director of vision. He's directed nearly five films(with Black Swan coming out next month) and most of them have been visionary. Though one man's vision could only go so far. Critics hated Arronofsky's 3rd vision, The Fountain. Probably for the same reason they hated Vanilla sky. You know what... I liked Vanilla sky. And I liked this movie too.

I will do my best to comprehend the plot. Hugh Jackan and Rachel Weiz play a couple. Jackman's a scientist, Weiz is a writer. Jackman tries his best to keep her alive when he finds out that she has a tumor. Going on around the time of the Spanish armada or something like that, Jackman plays a conquistador who's trying to save the princess(Rachael Weiz). And going on in heaven or something, Jackman is trying to save his wife(Rachael Weiz).

I tried my best to summarize the plot. I think I got it wrong. I understood most of the film while I was watching it. I couldn't fit some things together. Such as"What is going on?" It took me about an hour out of 90 minutes to figure out the actual plot of this film.

The film has a lot of spectacles. The effects are dazzling. The film is trippy and weird. Just like something Arronofsky or Richard Kelly would come up with. Critics shouldn't have bashed this film. Arronofsky had a vision, he brought it out, not many people got it.

I understood the majority of it. The film probably needed to be more clear than it was. Instead of just presenting these things on the screen. The fountain looks great. It is a success visually. It, in my opinion, works as a film. Give it a chance.Visualize with Arronofsky.

B+

title: Best Film of the Decade
review:
Death is a subject that most people do not feel comfortable discussing and probably never will. That is why when a film that touches on death so intimately is released that is something special.

Darren Aronofsky initially came up with the idea for this film when reading about a prisoner who was in the prison of a small Latin American town. A volcano erupted and killed everyone in the village but the one prisoner in the new prison. Then the idea of being the last man alive became the main crux of the script. Of course when writing about immortality, the issue of death comes up instantly, and Aronofsky incorporated that into the story. The obsession we as a culture have about remaining eternally young and dismissing death in its entirety is a major part of the tragedy of The Fountain. That while we care for our loved ones we are never really spiritually there for them when the time comes.

The story begins at the foot of a giant temple in 1500's Spain. Tomas is one of three men remaining on a journey that started with the search of the fabled Tree of Life. The natives come out with spears and our three conquistadors have realized they are in a trap. The other two men are killed instantly, but Tomas fights like a caged animal and eventually is knocked down and carried by the mob to the steps. At their beckoning Tomas climbs the pyramid and once at the top sees a glimmer of what so many lives have been lost for: the Tree of Life. However the tree is not unguarded and Lord of Xibalba is there with his sword of flame to protect the gift of First Father. Tomas engages him and is stabbed, the Lord goes for the death strike and with the sounds of Tomas's scream we are transported to the year 2500.

Tom Creo is suspended in a bubble colliding through space at a rate of speed one cannot even imagine. Tom shakes off the dream that frightened him so and moves to the tree encapsuled in the bubble. He kneels close to it and whispers, "Through that last dark cloud is a dying star. And soon enough, Xibalbia will die. And when it explodes, it will be reborn. You will bloom...and I will live." A figure appears out of the dark of the screen and it is a woman standing outside of Tom's vision. "Take a walk with me," she coos but Tom shakes his head, "I have too much work." She prods again, "It's the first snow, we always..." her voice softens but Tom can still not go. We don't know what work he is referring to as he is the only man alive with foreseeably nothing around. And then again with an utterance we are transported back to the year 2005. Tommy is sitting at his desk going over research and waiting on the word to go to surgery. Tommy is a neurosurgeon and his wife Izzy has a brain tumor that is terminal.

I cannot give enough credit to Hugh Jackman who plays all three characters in The Fountain and also delivered another captivating performance that year in The Prestige. Nothing emotionally in this film was handcuffed by a fake display of anguish, Jackman delivered it all, from the soul. Could you imagine how this line, "Death is a disease, it's like any other. And there's a cure. A cure - and I will find it." could have been butchered in lesser hands? Rachel Weisz really makes for compelling viewing as the cancer-stricken wife of Tommy. Forced to come to terms with death on her own Izzy is the heart of The Fountain and the foil for Tommy, who refuses to accept her ailment and races to find a cure. Even at the risk of his own sanity.

Perhaps what is most amazing about The Fountain is that 98% of the film was done without CGI. All of the space seen around Tom are micro-sized photographs of chemical reactions. The cinematography is the hands-down best I have seen in film ever. Matthew Libatique (who has been Aronofsky's cinematographer since Pi) reigns in your interest and keeps it while never resorting to distracting the audience with cheap parlor tricks.

The Fountain arrests the mind, breaks the heart and is the best film of the decade.

title: Incredible Surrealistic imagery, fantastic cinematography and spellbinding performances, can't compensate for an often sluggish movie.
review:
The Fountain is a very well done movie, no doubt about it. The cinematography is fantastic, the performances by Hugh Jackman and Rachel Weisz are absolutely spellbinding, the imagery is absolutely wonderfully surreal, and the story is at times very interesting. It's just even for just over 90 minutes, the pacing is often very sluggish, which made for a very trying experience at times. You have to pay strict attention to this film, you can't miss one little detail, or your pretty much screwed. I think I got a lot of this movie anyway. They are all inter wined together, all the three stories, anyway. The most interesting one for me, had to be the one where Hugh plays the scientist. It felt the most real, and to me was by far the most heartfelt. The least effective was the one in Midevil times. The imagery near the end made my jaw drop almost literally. I have honestly never seen anything like that, in my entire life. It was beautiful, haunting, and surreal all at the same time. The Fountain is far from a failure, and there is a lot of interesting stuff on hand, but it's just too sluggish a lot of the time, for my liking.

Performances. Hugh Jackman is utterly incredible here. His multi layered performance is something for the ages. Each character he played, he poured his whole heart into. His chemistry with Rachel is what chemistry is all about. Together the two bring realism, and pure love, I was often amazed by the two. Rachel Weisz is excellent. She is charming ,vulnerable, yet strong at the same time. She has a hypnotizing face, and I often couldn't take my eyes off of her. Ellen Burstyn is very good here, per usual. She didn't have much screen time, when she did though, she added a lot of class to the part.

Bottom Line. The Fountain is a movie I was very much half and half on. I enjoyed a lot of the experience, I was floored by the imagery, and the ending was one of the strangest, yet most incredible things I have ever seen. It just is much to slow for its own good sometimes, and ultimately that's what killed it in the end for me. I do however recommend it for an evening watch, just make sure you pay strict attention, or you will be lost.

title: The story to ascension
review: I want to start out by saying I'm 22yr's old. I liked this movie a lot. It has great cinematography and fantastic acting. But thats not what fascinates me. Its the fact that from the start this very ambiguous jigsaw puzzle is presented to the viewers with only a few pieces in place. It makes no sense yet visually its beautiful. This puzzle represents what the film is trying to say. It is distorted and made harder to understand by the three different story lines, which work excellent in conveying the different types of courage and determination of the martyr played by Hugh Jackman. I like how the movies uses other times in history to convey to same ambition, just different ways of trying to reach his goal. This makes the movie interesting and really reflects this nearly plot less movie something with direction. I see a spiritual aspect to this movie as well. I can't help but think this is a lot more deeper than what people really understand. I think this movie is about the one soul replaying the same life over and over again until he finally realizes what he really should be focusing on, (Sorry to go all Carlos Castaneda) that accepting death and not living in the shadow of the thought opens your perception to new thought and possibilities. When he finally accepts death and doesn't fear it he ascends. To me the puzzle still isn't complete because I cant fully comprehend a fair bit of this movie. I like to think thats what its about.

title: One of the best and most unique movies not just of its kind
review:
One of the best movies out there. Having its viewers to interpret the movie individually for themselves it left me thinking about it long time after I watch it. Great panorama and extraordinary special effects( please! watch this with high definition source and big screen TV ,it will be an awesome experience) ,best actors(Hugh Jackman and for my personal taste most beautiful actress Rachel Weisz),wonderful soundtrack( i had to buy one) and unique approach of science fiction and romance( made me almost cry..i sad almost) make this motion picture stick out of any other movie i ever saw.

Really pity it was not big commercial success for such an effort when some garbage of the movies out there make way more money. Hopefully not only financial success will be main guidance for Hollywood bosses to allow more of such a great movies to be produced.

Definitely "a must see" category spectacle.

title: A fascinating and enchanting film!
review:
Well, ladies and gentlemen, Darren Aronofsky has done it again! He is one of my favorite directors and screenwriters but this movie, in my humble opinion, completely transcended his other gems Pi, Requiem for a Dream, and more recently The Wrestler. This tale takes its audience on a breathtaking journey through some of the most enthralling visuals in cinematic history (almost all done without any CGI at all! Unprecedented in today's era of lazy film makers!) Aside from the breathtaking eye candy, the story this movie tells is very touching, heartwarming, and thought provoking and tells the story of love, loss, devotion, and obsession in a very unique and powerful way.

And the cast! Brad Pitt was originally slated to play the role of Tommy/Tomas but for some reason he left the project and was replaced with Hugh Jackman. Honestly, I truly believe that this movie is all the better for it! I admit that I was never a huge Hugh Jackman fan before watching this movie but I was an instant convert after watching this back in '07. And I frown very sternly at anyone who says that Rachel Weisz only got her part because she's involved with Aronofsky. She was brilliant and has incredible chemistry with Jackman! Add onto this a stellar supporting cast with Academy Award winner and Requiem for a Dream alumni (and ever lovely) Ellen Burstyn at its center.

Lastly, but certainly not least, is the soundtrack. Clint Mansell provides a genius accompaniment to this movie. It sets the tone in a way words cannot describe. I am normally one who doesn't pay much attention to a film's musical score. But this one is impossible to ignore or forget. It is a masterpiece of movie music.

My only disappointment about this movie was that I was unable to see it in theaters where I believe it would have been all the better. You will understand after you see the movie and hear its music.

I don't want to say much else about the movie in order to avoid spoiling its magic. All I can say is "Seriously, watch it.....Dude, what are you waiting for? Get your butt down to the video store and rent this...NOW!"

11/10

title: We are left in awe!
review: Death is hanging – the inquisition over Isabel's' Spain, cancer over Izzi In the navel of Earth a Mayan temple houses the tree of life; above it a golden supernova named Xibalba. We are told how in Mayan legend the first Man created the tree of life by sacrificing himself - the tree burst from his stomach, his head became Xibalba and the roots became Earth. We are told by Izzi how on a trip to Mexico her guide Moses told her "that if they dug his father's body up it would be gone. They planted a seed over his grave. The seed became a tree. Moses said his father became a part of that tree. He grew into the wood, into the bloom. And when a sparrow ate the tree's fruit, his father flew with the birds. He said... death was his father's road to awe. That's what he called it. The road to awe. Now, I've been trying to write the last chapter and I haven't been able to get that out of my head!" Isabel/Izzi pulls Tomas/Tom through time. The tree is his map. The story is finished through acceptance – of the first man's sacrificial death and of the death of isabels' body that received infinite love A seed is planted in her body. Death-supernova explodes. It is finished. We have walked the road to awe. Body-root-earth and mind-cosmos-supernova somehow unite. We are left in awe!

title: A Visual and Visceral Feast
review:
As a fan of Darren Aronofsky's work since it all began with Pi, i was eagerly anticipating this film; a long time in the making.

Unfortunately for me, it was pulled from theatre's just weeks after it first aired, and the reasons are so painfully clear.

This is not a film for the average popcorn flick cinema goer. whilst seemingly complex the basic premise is simple; "love conquers all". However this theme seemed to elude casual cinema goers with an at first awkwardly strung plot line between what appears to be three different characters.

Upon subsequent viewings one can safely say that the plot line is much more tangible and not as difficult to follow as first presumed.

A man tortured by the memories of a love he lost, and his gradual, painful acceptance of death. Jackman is fantastic and this film really shows off his theatre background. Seldom has a performance moved me like this, the last i can recall is Jim Carrey in Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.

Weisz is fantastic in the role of Izzi, she has a certain glow to her in anything she does, and her and Jackman's chemistry is quite unique and above all, believable.

The emerging themes of death as an inevitability coupled with the age old formula of mans struggle against immortality make for something truly special. Visually stunning and emotionally articulate The Fountain delivers something that Hollywood should be striving to do more often.

Clint Mansell's soundtrack is sublime. Working closely with the Kronos Quartet and Scottish rockers Mogwai (a personal favourite of mine) the sound produced from this dream trio is something utterly indescribable and without this musical input, the film would not have had the impact that it had and still has. Even after viewings in the double figures.

A film that i'm sure will become a cult classic in many years to come, but sadly misunderstood and unfortunately labelled "pretentious" by many casual cinema goers.

The Fountain is a film you have to watch as it is difficult to define in words, make up your own mind, and we'll see where this film is in ten years time...

title: Ambitious and ultimately rewarding, but falls a bit short of the mark
review:
Darren Aronofsky's name will almost exclusively be linked with the amazingly awesome REQUIEM FOR A DREAM, and in his latest offering, Aronofsky's genius once again comes to the forefront in an impressively ambitious Motion Picture that is full of atmosphere and emotion, but eventually will be described as a film that one appreciates but does not really 'like'.

Part of the problem was its running length of about 90 minutes, which I felt was too short a time to convey what Aronofsky wanted to accomplish. For the first half-hour or so, I myself was unsure of what the film's overall purpose was. A lengthier, better-paced movie may have been better suited to an undertaking of this magnitude. My other problem was that the three stories did not intertwine as well as they should have at many times, and themselves felt like separate short stories.

Nonetheless, I applaud this Motion Picture for its ambition, its vision, its story, its acting (Hugh Jackman and Rachel Weisz were quite spectacular), and its breathtaking and mood-setting score.

Overall, a solid 8/10 and 3 stars (out of 4). If only more filmmakers had the vision and the drive to undertake a project of this scope. Recommended, especially for those seeking a unique, strange, and ultimately rewarding Motion Picture about the quest for Everlasting Life, and the Certainty of Death.

title: beautiful movie , a potential killer - slightly spoiled by melodrama
review:
I made the mistake and read about this movie on IMDb before watching it actually, and had higher expectations. Although I was not completely disappointed, I had a feeling that it could be a killer movie if it was slightly less over-dramatized and more subtle in storytelling. The film has some memorable, haunting moments with beautiful visuals, and some unnecessary nearly-pathetic twists which spoiled the overall feeling for me.

The main theme of the movie is the inner struggle of a man with the idea of mortality, and a spiritual voyage towards the affirmation of life through accepting death. The story is told in three threads. It captures the viewer's attention with unusual settings (a Conquistador in Mayan world, and a translucent sphere floating among stars - I would not call it a spaceship as it is often described by reviewers here, but more like a depiction of the voyage trough the inner universe of the main character. This is the most fascinating scene in the movie in my opinion.) The movie switches between these two "fictional" worlds and the third "real" world of a doctor and his wife (although I think it is futile to discuss which one is the "reality" because this is absolutely irrelevant for the main theme and message of the movie). There are a few interestingly depicted archetypal images (man trying to conquer death for his queen, tree of life, death giving life). Initially the warmness of the relation of the doctor and his wife contrast nicely the odd and surreal feeling of other two realms, but then it suddenly veers in to a melodrama. This distraction is not enough to ruin the movie though, and it still remains a remarkable piece of cinematography. It should be viewed more than one time, and for the first time, if possible with someone close to you. Not recommended for impatient/instant fun and action/instant answers/must be happy end/is this real or not/ types.

title: A brilliant movie!
review: A brilliant movie that contains everything from love and the pain of loving to searching for a liberating knowledge through any means possible to an honorable man. Hugh Jackman is truly impressive in this film! I have watched the film now four times, and always find new things and depths in it. And I will see it again, if for nothing else then for the wonderful, breathtaking music that in its monotony and repetitive magic catches your soul, and along with the story, takes it to new levels. A film like this immediately makes you think what else the director Darren Aronofsky has made, and it also made me appreciate more than before the acting talent of Mr Jackman. Great work by the whole team!

title: Goes well until the last 20 minutes, and then it just becomes absurd
review:
Visually exciting. Fabulous staging and lighting. The sets are well done and the acting is superb.

But the story is a muddled mess. The Astronaut story is, in particular, just muddled, silly, and disconnected from the rest of the story. And the sight of Hugh Jackman doing yoga is simply silly.

Despite all that, the movie holds together quite well until the last 20 mins when the Conquistador meets the Mayans. What the hell is happening here? What is that scene with the Mayan priest when suddenly Jackman is in a lotus position, floating in mid-air. And that is followed by the Astronaut scene where the tree dies, and then he separates from the bubble to do what? Just float away.

The ending is silly and unconnected to the rest of the story. It was like someone else wrote it. 5 out of 10, mostly for visual effects and great acting. Writing gets a 1 out of 10.

title: Why The fountain should be felt, not viewed.
review:
I read the baronesses comment earlier and i felt her dry and negative review of the ending. She talks about the movie not supposed to just seen as a story but felt and that, i think, she did not do. The ending, she says, was nothing but a golden crescendo over the top of which ruins the movie a bit. I on the contrary feel that the ending is one of the most beautiful parts in the entire production. As the film should be felt i felt the ending. I did not see (spoiler) a man in space in a bubble, i saw a mans final destination on a road, traveled through pain and denial. The way he finally meets his end and receives the peace and love he so long struggled unfruitlessly for to remain within his grasp moves me in a way not many other films have and I'd like to extend my gratitude's to the producer.

So baronessa, i see his journey through his wives death in the metaphors which are shown in different ways. In the book and in his inner self (space).

I apologize for any bad English or unchecked grammar/ spelling.

title: Darren Aronofsky's best film to date!
review:
I remember seeing the previews for this movie in theaters, and saying I want to see that, but when the film came out I completely forgot about it. Then the other day I saw it laying on a store shelf at my local DVD store, and I decided to pick it up. Now Darren Aronofsky is in my opinion one of the finest filmmakers out there right now. His works sport unique concepts filled with endless imagination, that you never really find in American films nowadays. Aronofsky got his start doing low budget Indy films; and finally with the Fountain, Aronofsky has the money to just let his imagination run free, and he delivers his best film to date.

The story of the Fountain is about one man's search for immortality over the course of a thousand years, resulting in a story that is both about the meaning of life and death.

As mentioned the film, which was both written and directed by Aronofsky, is simply amazing. The direction is crisp, the cinematography is a wonder to behold, the score is magnificent sound to go along with the visual splendor, and the acting from this stellar cast is terrific, in particular the performance from Hugh Jackman.

The Fountain is simply one of the best films I have seen in a long time, it is heartbreaking and emotional, while also being terrific eye candy; and just like any other film from Darren Aronofsky, you must be willing to go into unexplored territory. If you are wanting a safe movie that follows all of the typical guidelines for drama films, then this isn't for you; but if you want a movie that takes you places dramatically that no other movie has ever dared to go, then you will love the Fountain.

Aronofsky has outdone himself here with a true classic for the ages.

I give the Fountain a perfect 10 out of 10!

title: Simply Amazing
review:
There has been no movie which has moved me enough to write a review, except this one. This film is one for the ages and as some may say way ahead of its time.

First off it is not for everyone. It is an art film which has great acting, amazing visual, and a beautiful score. The story is complex and emotionally driven. Now I must say this again it is an ART film and not for everyone.

This film dares to be different and does it with an emotional roller coaster of love and death. Its has a minimal amount of CGI which elevates the film. Hugh Jackman and Rachel Weisz deliver captivating performances in this thoughtfully written story. In short it is a wonderful piece of art which brings pure and true emotion.

title: Spirals of divinity
review: In the last decade, I can say that no movie has been more horribly underrated than this gem of dramatic film-making. The Fountain is, in essence, a tribute to our vulnerability and our fear and simultaneous acceptance of the unknown. Jackman and Weisz don't create chemistry so much as they attempt to tear out your heart strings. They're ability to communicate the ocean of love, bewilderment and trepidation in Aronofsky's story is something that borders on magical. Admittedly, the story telling is labyrinthine and incredibly high on its demands, but the giving in is the great reward in unlocking the message running intravenously through the film. And while critics may claim that the film reaches to high, for too much, it's over-thinking the Fountain's core message that can sour its taste. I'm confident in saying this is one of my favorite films of all time. It speaks through loving, universal tongues and goes places few are comfortable in exploring in film. If this film doesn't send you away with stars in your eyes and the human condition heavy on your mind, then you need to take a breath and give it another shot. It's nothing short of a marvel, one that unwraps differently each time you come back to it and like any film worthy of timeless distinction, you can never watch it too much to not feel moved.

review: I don't know about you but there have been a lot of movies over the years that have been overlooked and this movie is one of them. Rent it, buy it, trust me, it really gets you emotionally.

title: Charlie's Review of The Fountain
review:
"The Fountain" is Darren Aronofsky's visual poem about life, death, eternal life, love, obsession, hubris, belief, fear, and truth. If this strikes you as a lot to deal with in the context of one film, you're right, it is. Nonetheless, I have never seen a director present this much profound thematic material in a more artistic and economical fashion than what Mr. Aronofsky has accomplished in this film. For only having directed two previous films (the excellent "Pi: Faith in Chaos", and the harrowing yet brilliant "Requiem For A Dream"), it is amazing that Darren Aronofsky has already proved himself to be one of the best artists working in the medium of film by creating a provocative, balanced work that demands as much of an intellectual response to it's themes as it does an emotional one.

In his third, and most mature work yet, Aronofsky uses the idea of "the fountain of youth", along with the imagery of "the tree of life", to meticulously establish the theme of humanity's desire and journey to find the means of achieving eternal life. Aronofsky, who is scrupulous in his design and composition of every shot (one of the elements of his approach to film making that merits strong comparisons to Stanley Kubrick), infuses the film with recurring imagery of circles and rings that articulate the theme of eternal life and (with the use of a wedding ring) eternal love. This repetitive structure in the film also allows the movie to generate an emotional sensation from the audience that is more analogous to the effect poetry creates, opposed to the resulting sensation produced by a narrative. It is this daring decision by Mr. Aronofsky that makes this film so unique, as well as so misconstrued by critics and audiences alike.

"The Fountain" introduces the audience to three characters, all played with superb power by Hugh Jackman, and who all bear a variation of the name Thomas. The central persona of the three, or at least the character that functions within a world that the audience can most readily identify with, is Tommy Creo- a doctor trying to discover a cure for cancer, ultimately to save his wife who is dying from a brain tumor. The last name "Creo" is similar to the Spanish word for "I Believe". This is an interesting connection, not only thematically, but also because it links this modern day "Tom" with the other character Jackman plays, Thomas- a Spanish Conquistador in search of the Fountain of Youth. The third semblance Jackman takes on is Tom- an explorer of the stars who is traveling through space in the 26th Century with a tree (the Tree of Life?) that he repeatedly eats the bark off of; an action which Aronofsky clearly associates with the Christian practice of the Eucharist. This trinity of Thomas's is driven by their love, or obsession, with Izzy or Isabel, played luminously by Rachel Weisz. All three "Toms" are seeking to find a way to overcome the reality of death and live eternally in their love with this woman. The sequence of events that take place around these characters function as an emotional catalyst that propels the characters and themes toward a breath- taking montage* sequence which delivers a climax that presents many questions and answers that will require each person who views the film to interpret and understand the symbols, events, themes, and characters with whatever worldview or experiential framework they bring with them when they see it. This allows the film to change and grow with every viewing, as well as with each new viewer. Herein lies Aronofsky greatest achievement with this film. The postmodern foundations that permeate the entire film, as well as it's poetic nature, makes it possible for anyone to bring an interpretation to the film that is representative of the viewer's background, and yet still be a valid elucidation of the sequences that occur within the film. Aronofsky's inventiveness in creating this type of philosophical and poetic vision makes "The Fountain" a work of art that can be clearly felt by anyone who can cope with its logical elusiveness.

"The Fountain" also boasts a transcendent yet melancholy score by Clint Mansell that saturates the film with even more emotional complexity. The cinematography by Matthew Libatique is another amazing achievement that portrays a visual motif of golden lighting and textures that seems to direct the viewer to contemplate man's lust for gold and the material world. This film only grows stronger the more I see it, so for those who have yet to experience "The Fountain" here is your invitation to discover "the road to awe".

title: Agood-looking film that makes you think
review:
Firstly, I won't attempt to describe the plot, as, frankly, even after reading the Wikipedia article, I didn't fully understand it. However, I'd like to make a few comments:

1. It's a very good-looking film, which reminded me of the early films of Ridley Scott - from The Duellists (a personal favourite) through "Someone to Watch over me".

2. My main problem with the plot (or losing it!!) was what I now understand to be "the astronaut". I thought he was Buddha, or a Buddhist priest, and was completely confused. However, the working title of the film - The Last Man - suggests he maybe is the last human, and, like in "Sunshine", is on a mission to save humanity and, also like in "Sunshine", sacrifices himself to save The Tree - and humanity. Also, I think I remember him walking on water, after killing the Mayan priest, to reach The Tree. Another Jesus allusion?

3. All through the film there is a scene of the researcher refusing to go for a walk in the snow with his (terminally) ill wife. Robert Burns put it far better than I in his poem "Here's a bottle" with the verse:

"Catch the moments as they fly, and use them as ye ought, man; believe me, happiness is shy, and comes not aye when sought, man."

By the end of the film the researcher regrets not going for the walk.

4. Hugh Jackman plays the multiple roles - from "Buddha", to a swash-buckling conquistador, to an obsessive doctor like Jeremy Irons' dual role in "Dead Ringers" - brilliantly. Rachel Weisz, as the Queen, has never looked more beautiful.

I'll definitely watch this film again and, probably, again.

title: Achingly beautiful and genuinely moving
review:
Firstly, I do not know how Darren Aronofsky was able to direct this film with his partner, Rachael Weisz, as the beautiful, captive queen and dying wife, without crying every few minutes whilst working on the film. Actually, did anyone on this film manage a day without being touched by its aching emotion particularly its representation of desperation felt when faced with the dying of a loved one? And this emotion is not simply played out, but the marvel and originality of the film is seeing this horrible reality explored through such highly imaginative story lines and symbolism.

The key to the film is to understand that one storyline is a present reality, whilst the other two are imaginative explorations (written by the two characters in the "present" reality) of the themes of dying, seeking life and holding onto a loved one.

The film is absolutely stunning in its original vision with dense, poetic and symbolic imagery linking each of the stories together. Certain images such as the tree of life, the nebula and Weisz herself as the Spanish queen, are so beautiful they will remain with me forever. You need to pay attention as rewards come when you can recognise even certain camera angles repeating themselves throughout the three stories, unifying them.

Because the film is unconventional in its storytelling and daring in its other-worldly imagery, it requires actors whom you immediately relate to, and Rachael Weisz and Hugh Jackman are perfectly cast in these roles. They convey a real conviction in their acting and genuinely seem to convey heart-breaking fragility, strength and pain.

I would recommend this film to anyone with sensitivity, empathy imagination and soul.

title: Road To Awe
review:
MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS OR QUOTES.

'What if you could live forever?'' The Fountain is one of the deepest movies I've ever had the pleasure to witness. If you follow it through to its conclusion and are open minded, a deep thinker then it becomes gratifyingly mind-blowing. As for the tree of life and Izzi's book, is it real? Is she the tree? Or maybe Tom and Izzi are both a combined element of the tree in the end, the Tree representing or being their eternal love in essence them.

Guess the main message is accepting death and its hard to lose a loved one. I could watch this film over and over, and still pick up different ideas from it. People will understand this film one day, maybe when were more evolved mentally, we've all closed our minds.

I think to the best of my ability I understand The Fountain now. I accept what other people think because end of the day I'm in awe of something that is unlike most material, that isn't afraid of being hated by a religious or material obsessed public. Always seems whatever card you play, the more stupid people become. The tree she is, he is, entwined in love. Some people think this film is about death or life, that it is sad, the truth is in between, death is the road to awe.

Death as a means of life, falls on deaf ears in todays zombie-like society. All in our little boxes or one track thoughts. We want a movie that has a basic plot, simple characters, that forever keep changing titles but in essence end up all the same. Well I don't want that, thats why Fountain is so special to me because it explores the whole notion of Death, Rebirth and Love, not to mention the difficult process of losing a loved one and how we would do anything to save them. In essence sometimes we can't change something that's destined to happen, which begs for the old acceptance and to let the river run its course which remains the real message. The Fountain is neither stereotypically happy or sad to me, in the end its resolute, a simple Zen-like fable bordering on rebirth and love eternal.

The parts played beautifully by Hugh Jackman and Rachael Weisz and the love they feel for each other is for me genuinely believable. One scene near the end where he is looking at her like an embodiment of memories, of realities where the Queen Isabella and Izzy merge, is wondrous to behold. Which begs me to wonder if the book Izzi writes isn't something made up from her imagination but one where she has remembered a previous life. Queen Isabella being one of he incarnations. Aztec beliefs also strangely mirror Buddhist ideas in a ''Death is the road to Awe'' sacrificial sense, underlining First Father and Rebirth. Which also makes me think the future Tom, is he not Tom at all or the embodiment of First Father. In essence is he First Father? Darren Aronofsky has a talent for looking at things that I think is so close to my own reflection and thoughts on higher things. Upon reflection Fountain is very similar to Requiem but does it in a more spiritual approach.

Darren's fascination with Mortality has always been there, just go back to Pi with the conversation at that Coffee Shop concerning the Tree Of life. The Fountain will cut Movie Lovers down the middle one half thinking it's cult inducing hippy trash about some bald guy in a bubble and the other half truly seeing it for the deep visual entrancing Journey of one man's struggle with Death, in a race against time to try to save his wife.

A masterpiece of Film Fountain belongs with 2001 and even Requiem for it's higher meaningful depictions. Each time I watch it there's always another piece, another juicy mesmerizing question raised that I didn't see before.

title: I didn't really get it....
review:
Okay it was really beautifully done! But I didn't really get it.... The actors were amazing, when you think you know whats going on the story changes again... and again. It's pretty much about a guy who does not except death. I watched it with my little cousin, who through the entire movie kept asking me what was going on.
