Director Darren Aronofsky deserves mountains of praise for conceiving such an ambitious and remarkably inventive feat. While his screenplay may occasionally drift into being confusing or frustrating, with extensive use of stilted dialogue and cutting in between the story's three time periods, it never affects one's enjoyment of the film - there is far too much to appreciate going on for the occasional small irritation to affect. The film's visuals, if nothing else, are worth immense credit alone - never before have such dazzling effects, as well as brilliant cinematography, inventive, stunning sets and costumes been used to such superb effect. Aronofsky avoided using CGI effects for the futuristic sequences, instead superimposing microphotography of reactions in petri dishes, and it really shows how even in such a computer saturated world as today, stunning visuals can be created without spending millions on technological costs. As well as being one of the most philosophically daunting and thought provoking films of the decade, The Fountain also proves to be arguably the most visually sumptuous movie in recent memory. Clint Mansell's exquisitely moody score is similarly beautiful, and perfectly compliments the edgy yet beautiful tone of the film.

Hugh Jackman has been proving himself to be one of the most fearless, talented and charismatic actors of his generation, and he gives one of his strongest and most emotional performances to date. Playing three characters in radically different time periods simultaneously, Jackman captures our sympathies through his characters' mutual passion, drive and dedication - few other actors would have been capable of such a moving performance. Rachel Weisz, Aronofsky's wife, matches Jackman at every turn, delivering a mystical and captivating performance through each time period. Though the supporting cast is sparsely used, Ellen Burstyn stands out as a caring doctor in the twentieth century storyline, though the film unquestionably belongs to Jackman and Weisz, who prove themselves more than up to the task.

It is highly difficult to describe such a radically unique film such as The Fountain - the film stands out as one of the most visually inventive, philosophical and soul searching efforts in recent history, completely unlike anything most viewers are likely to have ever seen before. Yet at the core of it all is a simple love story, which is executed with as much emotional weight and tenderness as any of the grandiose themes surrounding it. Is The Fountain a perfect film? No, though the word is hard to describe and really an entirely subjective quality anyway. What the Fountain does offer is an epic story of love and rebirth, spanning generations and complimented by simply stunning visuals. Don't expect necessarily to entirely understand the film upon first completing it, but instead allow it to blossom over time until it can be fully appreciated and respected. In a day and age so starved of originality, The Fountain is worth seeing simply for proof that fresh and touching work can still be produced, and that from the depths of commercial garbage, beauty can still emerge.

-9/10

title: There are no words...
review: The best movie I have ever seen! I will not even attempt to praise it for fear that words would not capture the essence of this film. However, because I need to fill up 10 lines worth of space, I can attempt to justify the film. A beautiful experience; like living, breathing art. Each scene is exquisitely beautiful. I have never left a film feeling so content; so satisfied. The actors were wonderful and Rachel's performance was, as always, beautiful. The film requires no explanation. I look forward to watching this film again and again! Thank you Mr. Aronofsky! This film will, of course, not be appreciated the way it should be and that is a damn shame because the film is fantastic!

title: The road to awe. . .mazement
review:
I was in Chandler, AZ in November of '06 on a business trip with my best friend. The only thing we did was go to see the movie The Fountain. A friend of his had recommended it and he trusted her judgment. We drove to the mall, only after getting lost a bit, and got our tickets and food and went to our theater.

Little did we know we were in for an almost overwhelming visual treat. The first half of the film I almost cried because I had never seen anything so beautiful. I thought all the effects were CGI induced but later found out Aronofsky chose to do the special effects for the film by using micro-photography of chemical reactions on tiny petri dishes. He has said that CGI would take away from the timelessness of the film and that he wants the film to stand the test of time. We had watched the trailer before hand and it gave me chills, I was rather excited to see this.

I keep reading reviews that say the movie dragged on, it wasn't good, didn't make sense or the like. Every moment held me in my seat, until that is people in the theater wouldn't stop talking and I had to alert someone. I am not a fan of Rachel Weisz by any means but in this movie I feel she really gave some substance to the role. I love Hugh Jackman, I always have. Aside from his action roles I believe him to be a great dramatic actor. From both of these actors I never knew they could inspire with so much feeling. I have never seen either of them so good in a role.

The movie plot itself appealed to me and seeing it for myself just made it all the more great. Who on this earth hasn't battled with thoughts and awareness of their own mortality? A theme Aronofsky craft fully spun into a mesmerizing and meaningful movie.

I am not totally unaware of the film maker. I have seen his moving movie about heroine addiction, Requiem for a Dream. He too cast Ellen Burstyn as Dr. Lillian Guzetti, Tom Verde's superior and friend. I believe her to be one of America's great actresses with a career spanning decades.

In this movie there are three periods of time we visit. Time of the Spanish Inquisition, present day, and somewhere in the future, with all stories intertwining in the last.

Izzi (Weisz) has inoperable brain cancer and her husband Tom (Jackman) tires by any means necessary to cure her. He says, "Death is a disease, it's like any other. And there's a cure. A cure - and I will find it." Working day in and day out, testing on animals, to save his wife. A story of a desperate man and a dying woman that is handled gracefully and poetically in the hands of Jackman and Weisz.

In the future Tom is haunted by the vision of his dead wife, ultimately losing the battle to save her in the past. His only company, a large tree. When she had died he planted a seed on her grave, something akin to a story she had told him, and it grew into this tree. The story she told him was of a Mayan guide, Moses Morales, from a trip she had taken. He said that if they dug his father's body up, it would be gone. They planted a seed over his grave. The seed became a tree. Moses said his father became a part of that tree. He grew into the wood, into the bloom. And when a sparrow ate the tree's fruit, his father flew with the birds. He said... death was his father's road to awe. That's what he called it. The road to awe.

His wife keeps haunting him about finishing the last chapter in the book she was writing just before her death. She couldn't finish it and asked him to complete the task. Riddled with strife and grief he fights and relishes these memories and her ghost. Unable to let go, until the end, sacrificing himself.

Accepting what has happened he joins her in Xibalba (pronounced "shibalba", where they are reunited. The pervasive theme in Aronofsy's film.

Quite truthfully it's one of the best movies I have ever seen and it has haunted me ever since, striking a deep chord within my own spirit with my own questions about life and death.

title: Visual poetry
review:
In Requiem for a Dream, director Darren Aronofsky and cinematographer Matthew Libatique used innovative techniques to mimic the effects of drugs taken by the film's protagonists, fish eye lenses deforming the living space and fast motion distorting the conversation time-frame. In The Fountain, the same team attempt to convey more of a mystical experience, with story layers little more than props for elaborate and stunning visual metaphors.

On a basic level, Hugh Jackman represents man's eternal struggle to save the woman he loves. In 16th Century Spain, he is a Conquistador searching for the Fountain of Youth in a Mayan Garden of Eden. When he succeeds, Queen Isabel of Spain will be his Eve. As a modern day scientist, he is trying to find a cure to save his wife, Izzi, who is dying of cancer and who is also writing a book called The Fountain. As a 26th Century astronaut, he is trying to grasp these mysteries that have always seemed just out of reach.

The genre and style of the film, like its subject matter, is elusive. At first, it seems determinedly weird, like David Lynch with no clues. As it develops, there is more than a nod to the elaborate aesthetic of films like Cremaster or the favourite of psychedelic cinema-goers, 2001. You become wrapped up in a visual overload of spectacular beauty (but if you were thinking of casually popping some acid before going to see it, you should be aware that there are also many dark, menacing images). This is no sanitised flight of fancy - it has more in common with Pan's Labyrinth than Star Trek. The futuristic images have an almost Matthew Barney -like organic evolution to them, whereas those of the Spanish Inquisition create a mandala of horror that fascinates at the same time that it shocks. A sense of Pandorian menace is rarely far from the explosion of visual beauty that constantly assaults our senses.

So what of the story? It is here that The Fountain is at its weakest. It creates intoxicating images of life, death, and re-birth but the theoretical connections are hazy at best. In the most developed of the tripartite, intertextual stories, Dr Tom Crio's experiments on monkeys will, he hopes, yield a method of shrinking the brain tumour affecting his wife. It is his love for her that motivates him to push beyond protocol. It also blinds him to the fact that he is making a remarkable scientific breakthrough - that of reversing the aging process. The film delicately weaves fringe science, Mayan myth, and symbols of the memories and inspirations that live forever when someone dies. We see the conflict of scientific and artistic temperaments - Tommy never, it seems, has enough time to explore the simple poetry of life with Izzi, with things like the first snow. She wants him to help her finish her book. "Please, leave me alone - I don't know how it ends," he says to her early on. The words haunt him later as they take on a different meaning.

A haunting score and remarkable special effects support a movie that has more talent than there were perhaps dollars to support. The Fountain is avant-garde and so far from the mainstream that you shouldn't even consider it unless you are prepared for a serious challenge. But if you are, you may be amply rewarded. The feint-hearted will dismiss it as a pretentious mess while aficionados will extol its haunting beauty. Whatever you do, don't even think of watching it on DVD.

title: Best movie of 2006!
review: The fountain by Darren Aronofsky is truly the best movie of 2006. I watched it during the Flanders film festival and I was shocked. People where actually sitting in the hallway because there wasn't enough room and people kept sitting there 3 minutes after the film had ended. The fountain is an experience that takes you through 3 different periods in time, each presenting a different atmosphere. The way Aronofsky and his whole cast do this is simply marvelous. The dark and primitive 1500's, the 'city that never sleeps' 2000 and the vast depths of space in 2500. The story is as brilliant as it is beautiful, love through the ages. Don't get me wrong, the fountain is a difficult movie and nodding of for a few minutes can cause a lot of confusion. But in exchange for your attention you get brilliant acting by a wonderful Hugh Jackman and a breathtaking Rachel Weisz, the most beautiful shots that the modern cinema has ever seen, and a story that fills your heart with so much love, hope and also sadness that you can't help but wanting to see this movie again. The reason this film was ripped of multiple oscarnominations is that it is not a crowd pleaser. It's a difficult film with a lot of symbolism. If the academy hadn't denied Darren Aronofsky's success. This film would have been a serious contender for Best Direction, Best Actor, Best Actress, Best actress in a supporting role, Best original score and Best Movie. It's a pity that films that can make a difference in the movie world are denied the respect and honor that they deserve.

title: Amazing
review:
This movie was not necessarily a film made to compliment the Hugh Jackman and Rachel Weisz, but it definitely is an award wining film!! The visual effects are a-mazing!! This movie is definitely a thinker so be prepare to think!! At some parts the film is very depressing, but overall the theme shines through: Ask yourselves, "What if you could live forever?" And then think about the film. This movie is definitely one of the year 2006's top 5 best films!! Hugh Jackman has made a breakthrough this year, this one, thus far this being the BEST!! Rachel Weisz (most recent Mummy Movies) has come a far way in success in recent area of films, "Constantine" etc. This is top notch for the CREW!!

I also know that the trailer is very deceiving while it does draw in viewers some people notice that one of the few comments made on the trailer about the movie was by MAXIM which in my own opinion would have thrown me off. The trailer also seems to show that it is mainly a love/ sci-fi movie which although is true is not what overall captivates you about the film. Again I think this movie is a top five of the year it's definitely a MUST SEE!!

title: Thank you Aranofsky
review: Thank you so much for this. I can believe how amazing this movie is. The Fountain is the next best thing out there. Everyone talks about Aranofky trying to be Kubrick, he is not. Aranofky is trying to be an amazing filmmaker in a league of his own. The Foutain is visually stunning, emotionally timeless. I give this movie a super rating. I am guaranteeing it will become a classic. 2001 was booed on it initial release, not it's classic because people need time to understand it's messages. The Fountain will become a classic when people are ready to understand it's messages. Unbelievable how Aranofsky knows these messages, he is ahead of us. bravo. 5 STARS. I love it.

title: Aronosfky the auteur
review:
There is something going on here. If I were to say that I knew what everything in The Fountain is supposed to mean, I'd probably be a damn liar. That said, I feel that I got the general idea. Many people have compared this film's esoteric, pseudo-intellectual appeal to something like Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey, but I think this is a wrong claim to make. There are many moments in the Fountain in which the story is too desperately being explained to us. Rachel Weisz is an amazing actress, but God bless her, half her lines in the movie feel like she's just spoon-feeding us important information. It took the joy away from a movie that should (though mostly does) communicate on an emotional level more than anything else. Even if you don't really know why, The Fountain has the ability to provoke some powerful emotions. Unfortunately, it does not do much else.

While watching the film, I sensed that Darren Aronofsky has become a director that believes in his own myth. People have called him one of the great contemporary directors, and now he has come up with this movie, which, at times, is just completely up its own ass. Fans of Aronofsky will no doubt love this and hail it as a triumph of the modern auteur.

If you were to remove the entire concept of past and future from the movie, you'd have a story of a man with a love so intense for the woman he lost, he would never, ever recover. Since we do get the other, more wondrous aspects to it, The Fountain becomes a more memorable, unique film, and has a beautiful sense of hope to it. It is a very one-sided love story though. It is mainly about Hugh Jackman's character's experiences. Aronosky's wife, the lovely Weisz, has to play a character who is never fully realized, and is degraded to an object of affection and goal for the main character, and someone who lays down all the important information to get the plot rolling.

I generally liked The Fountain, it had incredible visual effects that weren't CGI for once, it features a haunting musical score by Clint Mansell, good performances by Jackman and Weisz, and was emotionally hard-hitting. It's the the kind of film that just begs for repeat viewings, but it's honestly not as clever or deep as it thinks it is.

My rating: 7/10

title: A beautiful and creative story...
review:
... that wasn't put together with enough dummy clues to allow viewers who are unfamiliar with spiritual concepts a step-by-step instruction of what to think and believe. I was so relieved by this!

When you understand the philosophy behind the movie, the motives for the disjointed segments becomes clear. The funny thing is that the movie demonstrates that you don't have to understand! The Fountain has something for everybody, including those that call it junk, it's damned funny when you get it!

I loved the effects. I loved the moods and the sets. The acting was wonderful, I'm grateful that Pitt didn't get the part, not that he's not a good actor, but it just wouldn't have worked so well. The majority of the cast has already been proved, but this role gave Hugh Jackman a well-deserved chance to demonstrate his ability. And Weisz too. Such realism and passion, as those who have faced disease and death know what this looks like. There is so many valuable lessons in this movie. I'm literally just sitting here going "...wow." and wondering how to right it.

YOU MUST SEE THIS MOVIE!

I wished it were longer. I wish it had been me, any part of it. I can't wait for it to come out on DVD or blueray. The movie did poorly because it wasn't mainstream, but I hope that they don't stop making movies like this!

title: The Trouble With The Fountain?
review: After reviewing many sites, the consensus seemed to be that the movie was "hard to follow." I remember people spouting off the same comments about Highlander back in the 80s. It was not that The Fountain was hard to follow, for many I'm told after questioning; they realized they were unable to interpret the complex themes the movie presented, furthermore, the way the it was presented on-screen. What The Fountain is not: a typical Hollywood film. If you expected typical Hollywood action, drama, or other predictable works, bypass this movie and please see the next Bruckheimer film instead. The Fountain is an outside-of-the-box movie and should be appreciated for its simplicity and underlying message of love, religion, conquest and the human desire for immortality.

title: Wonderful
review:
An amazing movie with so much depth and meaning. Special effects were beautiful. A movie I will be purchasing. I found it to be thought provoking and stunning. I feel this movie is like a well written poem, every person that takes the time to view it will take away something completely different from it. I recommend if you get a chance of viewing this movie to view it with an open mind and with out any preconceptions.

A spectacular story that held my attention from beginning to end.

Again I look forward for this movie to come out on DVD so I may purchase it.

title: the movie explained as i see it
review:
i believe that the movie takes place like this.

what is really happening(2000) this is the center of the movie it is chronologically in the center and everything seems the relate to this.

then there is the past and that is izzys point of view of what is happing. she feels like she is a queen and her conquistador has come to save her and will risk it all, even himself for her (spain too).

then there is the future, this is toms point of view. he is trapped in a bubble racing against time to make the dieing tree(izzy) live. then just as in real life he is just too late and loses the tree and her the ending of the movie though, with him dieing. that only has him in it in all 3 time periods and i believe it represents him feeling greedy about her life. she was ready to go and he didn't want her to, so her kept working when she was there all along and he should have just enjoyed her and not been greedy then since he was greedy he lost her and ever got to enjoy her and now its too late. as far as him dieing, imnot really sure but maybe thats him feeling dead inside

title: Such a beautiful movie
review: A lot of people might not understand it at first but its a great movie. I love the entire plot. The costume designs. The way they filmed it. Hugh did a great job with his role. Every time he cried or smiled its like you could feel it. Every time he cried my eyes got watery. Rachel did an amazing job. Everything she does is great, shes an amazing actress. I loved the parts when she was bathed in white she looked stunning in those shots. It touches your heart how bad this guy wants to save his wife. That he would go to the ends of the world to save the woman he loves is truly inspiring. Aside from what most people will say about this movie its a one of a kind, truly beautiful in every sense of the word.

title: Like a Picaso
review: This movie is like a painting, a masterpiece to some, and a scribble to others. I loved it, everything about it. It's not a simple movie, the plot is not layed out for you in a traditional manner, it is a movie that you have to think with, you cannot just watch it and casually enjoy. If you have an acceptance for stories that do not fall within the norm, give this movie a chance. If you are not tolerant of new idea's and uniqueness, don't bother, you probably won't like it. I encourage you to watch the movie, and I encourage you to find a reason to like it afterward. I watched the movie with a friend in a theater with only three other occupants, two of which walked out not even halfway into the movie. Three out of five remained, not bad I'd say. I enjoyed the movie, and the next day I found myself pondering over the story trying to sort it out further. This was a masterpiece in my opinion, a true work of art.

title: Intensely Emotional and Visually Compelling
review: If you've ever been deeply, truly in love, this movie should affect you in profound ways. I rarely cry during movies, and though I kept most of my tears back during this one, I bit my lower lip so hard while trying to keep the flood back that my lip nearly bled. As with Aronofsky's other films (Pi and Requiem for a Dream), the imagery is compelling, beautiful, and sucks you in completely. Warning, though: if you see this with your significant other, be prepared to have an important discussion afterwards about love, life, and death. Also, if you're looking for something that you don't have to think about, go elsewhere (I saw American Dreamz a few days before and felt my brain going into sleep mode during that pap.)

title: Amazing piece of cinema
review: Before seeing this film I thought it was going to be an utter mess, i mean 90 minutes, spanning a thousand year period, yikes. Then while watching it i saw a masterpiece unfolding in front of my eyes. Where it is mistaken as a movie about the quest for immortality, it is really an amazing story of how a man overcomes a fear of death, and learns to embrace his own mortality in the fight to save his terminally ill wife. Darren Aronofsky does an amazing job of bringing the story he created as a graphic novel to the screen. This film is breathtaking visually and emotionally, and is an amazing follow up to his previous films(Pi, and Reqium for a Dream). With the addition of an absolutely beautiful score by Clint Mansell, this film will move you like no other film can. The Fountain also features an amazing performance by Hugh Jackman(X-Men, and The Prestige), as he masterfully plays three different roles in such a way you begin to question if it is even the same actor, also lets not forget to mention the performance of Rachel Weiz, who's almost angelic performance will make you instantly fall in love with her character. This movie is by far the best, and probably will become the most under rated movie of the year 2006. Writer/Director Aronofsky tells an amazing story that takes you on an emotional, and thought provoking trip that you will never soon forget.

title: Mixed Feelings
review: This movie is a great example of a movie that seems like it tries to hard. The acting is wonderful, the special effects and the music, are both top notch but this movie just leaves one very confused. It skips around more than a 60 year old scratched record. First I thought I was watching something that happened long ago in Spain...then all of a sudden the audience is sent into an orb floating somewhere in outer-space. Sure this is cool and everything but, I struggled to keep up in the beginning. Then as the plot unfolds and the audience comes to learn certain things about what is going on in the life of the main character; all of the symbolism of the movie starts to fall into place. However, it is not always a good thing to rely on so much symbolism to keep the audience interested in the movie. There were times where I thought I was going to pass out in the chair, other times I was asking my girlfriend what the heck was going on. It just seemed like the movie tried to complicate things, when the story is really very simple. All in all this was an entertaining movie. If you can put up with some confusion and slow moving scenes see this film. If you are not so artsy and like a straight-forward movie then this definitely isn't for you.

title: Movie Overview/Interpretation
review:
I must say, the fountain is a visually captivating film with terrific acting. I cannot emphasize how important it is to place trust in Aronofsky while watching this film, and follow his path through this cyclical adventure. This is not a linear story. If you cannot detach yourself from formulaic art you may not like this film. I have read quite a few negative criticisms on the film, and I write this to offer my interpretation to show that it is possible to appreciate this film aside from the gorgeous visuals. I am not saying the film goes without flaws, but what film is perfect? We see Thomas among 3 different landscapes of time. These landscapes could be interpreted as past, present, and future; and among each landscape the themes life, death, and knowledge are represented. In the past Thomas is a Spaniard who takes the mission from Isabel the Queen of Spain to find a cure against the diseased Spanish inquisition. The cure believed to be found in a sort of tree of life, and the sap of the tree is the cure. As Thomas closes in on the source of the cure, he is nearly fatally wounded, and therefore must use the cure on himself. Thomas is rebuilt from the sap. However, this life Thomas thought he was saving, that life being his own, is quickly met with a definition more becoming to the universe rather than to humans. His body is torn apart and reborn with earth. He recovered not his life as a human by the sap, but instead knowledge that there is no death, but a cycle of life. Thomas is not independent of the universe as a human, but instead an integral part of the universe as a tree to its roots, the roots to the soil, the rain to the soil, and so forth. Present day Thomas is a research oncologist who is again trying to find a cure for Izzi. His mission ill fated once again as the cancer's life engulfs Izzi's life. Izzi having cancer was a catalyst for Thomas's research. Though he could not save her life he did reach a break through, and with that knowledge he can prolong life for others. Finally, we see Thomas in the terrarium orb gliding through space. These segments of the film act as a mind's eye as well as another landscape. We see Thomas here traveling through the universe. However, we are moving on the path purposed by the knowledge bestowed by Izzi's book, The Fountain, to find the cure to death. In the end, the extension of life or cure to death is not found in our favor. The universe engulfs Thomas, as he was smaller vessel of energy he is now apart of a bigger energy in the universe. His body dies but he lives in the cycle of life. Explaining life as cyclical is not easy to portray in any medium. Aronofsky is an artist, a good one, and he should be supported. It would be a shame if we lost any future opportunities to see his work. I urge you to watch this challenging film, and let yourself see it. Don't waist your time and money and see it through the eyes of a quick to judge critic. There are many other themes I didn't touch on, but you will have to discover those on your own. If you enjoy this film I highly recommend the film "Slaughter House 5", and if you like these concepts research the symbol "Om".

Best Exploring

title: Bring It On Home
review:
"Zardoz anyone?" Sounds more like the stuff of keyboard vengeance that an honest review. I'll go ahead and take a step past the 2-cent quip. Is this film easy to understand? No. Is it easy to plot? No. Is a film of this individuality made often? No. Was I caught with a senior citizen's ticket by an usher? Yes. There have been others in cinematic history whose strangeness surpasses conventional standards and commands us to either accept its difference as enlightenment or refuse it as pretentious hogwash. 2001 has been mentioned so far in comparison but I might offer a more recent film like Terry Gilliam's Twelve Monkeys, which is not easily decipherable but like The Fountain asks the viewer to do some mental exercise and not just be bleached over with the predictability of moving from point A to point B.

Firstly, hats off to Brian Emerich and his crew. The sound design was amazing. Muted city noise toppled by the snow crunching footsteps of Jackman amplify how alone the character is in his quest while being surrounded by so many. From the sounds of intergalactic breakfast cooking in his cosmic conveyance, to the hairs whispering back in response to the sound of Hugh's voice summon the sense of beguiling sound that so rarely tantalizes a film audience. The score composed by Clint Mansell was mostly complimentary which I didn't find it as plodding as others have stated. If placed, I would have to say it sounded somewhere in the realm of Japanese-existentialist-keyboard-ponder-fest to music found in film classics such as Heat (night scenes of De Niro riding in his camaro) and Uncle Buck (listen to the scene sequence directly after Buck scares Bug with a 12 inch drill bit).

Trippy visual effects like kicking out the stars will send the most skeptical cerebrally enhanced big gulp drinker into gooey awe. Golden showers (it's a sci-fi thing, sorry) raining down and morning light brought in through the castle walls to illuminate Rachel Weiz are just a few of the optical morsels to take in.

The interweaving of time works fairly well, offering the circadian dimensions of time as plausible reality. Though I had trouble understanding the end fully or how Weiz's character became a tree in a bubble but I settled my thought's bones around it. It is just flat out confusing to know the origins of the future role Jackman plays. Where does he come from? Has he been traveling since present day? This part is so esoteric; I'm willing to bet when asked this question the witchiest of Mayan witch doctors would hop the 1st thing smoking back to Central America.

The whole concept of drifting through space working towards one seemingly ridiculous goal is futile but isn't that what so many of us do with our lives? The whole idea of eternal life wasn't in the main character's head until the Queen (Weiz) put it there. The roles for Hugh must have been exceedingly exhausting. He is (in many scenes) on the cusp of breaking down and in others his voice exudes the total frailty of an emotionally ruptured soul. His character was born to fulfill his loyalty (duties to Spain in the face of cultural cancer) and love is plainly a mission millions carry out and strives to protect everyday on our planet. Maybe I just can't see the harm in a kid walking out of the theater saying, "Dad, when I grow up I want to be a tai chi astronaut."

If we're accepting that God is at the helm regarding the film's universe, then the fact that present day Hugh is a brain surgeon and she has a tumor is totally plausible. If God is the great designer and time is circular, why wouldn't he just update the repeated lives we all live? He can't stop humans from advancing mentally but if he's in charge of time spent doesn't he write the fate of our eternal tickets? Hugh's character rails against all physical laws beset upon us. Religious or not I think its safe to say we can all agree that death is the inevitable equalizer.

This film is unique and because it does contain some grey area in its storyline, it makes for a highly debatable piece of work. Aside from that this film is definitely worth going to the theater for to obtain the overwhelming sensation you cant get on DVD.

title: Prepare yourself for an intense movie experience!
review:
I agree with Monotreme02's review above that this movie is unlike any I've seen in a long time. The reviews that I had seen prior to going had prepared me for parallel stories taking place in three different times including in the future, giving it a science fiction element. But that's not exactly how it was. Like Monotreme02, I am currently at a loss to know exactly how to describe it which is why I gave it only 8 stars--I feel like I should watch it again, to peel back a few more layers of meaning. Just when you think it's one thing, then it dissolves into being something else, and nothing is quite predictable (or at least it wasn't to me). Even just before the end something happened that I totally didn't see coming, yet made perfect sense and made me chuckle to myself, not because it was funny, but because I was so delighted at having been truly surprised. The movie is over two hours long but at no time did I sit there thinking I wish it would hurry up. It wasn't until well in that things began to be revealed that gave clues as to how everything ties together, but I didn't mind at all.

The actors' performances were indeed intense, Rachel Weisz in her reserved way and Hugh Jackman as a man who doesn't have control over certain events and whose frustration you can feel simmering just below the surface until, on occasion, it erupts. I was curious to see Hugh Jackman in something other than X-Men and I wasn't disappointed. It's all in his eyes.

And it was a visual stunner. Monotreme02 above has covered that adequately, as well as the understated musical score which I, too, found to be a perfect compliment to what I was watching.

For me, the final indication that this was a movie that had had some kind of effect on the audience was the complete silence that greeted the start of the closing credits, with nobody stirring for a good minute after they started rolling, due having been riveted by what they just saw.

title: I like The Fountainm but I don't expect everyone will.
review:
The Fountain is a great movie - for some. It is pure cinematography with a solid storyline, yet the transitions sometimes cause people headaches. My own brain had to transition actively to keep up, and I can only say you should experience the movie, not qualify/quantify each part.

Some of the flashbacks change as you are moved along in the movie. In one instance, Tom doesn't walk with his wife into the first snow of the year. Later, in another flashback, he does. How can this be? I found nothing wrong with that transition. I believe in reincarnation, but one that places time itself as an unimportant side note. If time was of no consequence, what would happen to your reincarnation? You'd come back as a person in the future as well as in the past - you'd also reincarnate sideways in time, meaning, at the same time. You and I are the same soul. Gives a broader, deeper definition to the Golden Rule, doesn't it?

How does this apply to The Fountain? When you transcend the logical, bestial world as I saw Tom do, time and all of 'nonsense' vanish - its not important. He didn't initially walk with Izzie into the snow, but later after transcending himself and truly becoming one with everything, he did walk with her. Beautiful. Transcendent.

In other words, this film was perfection. For me. Hate it, love it, be neutral about it. It isn't important that you fit in the group or feel insulted by others opinions of your opinion. That said, at least SEE IT!

title: Like Beautiful Poetry
review:
Fantastic film. When I first finished The Fountain I truly did not know what to think. I just stared at the screen not knowing if I loved or hated the film. I now can't stop thinking about it. The more my mind dwells on it, the more brilliance i find within it. Many moviegoers don't bother investing time outside of the theater to truly reflect on a film. I assume that many are viewing this, in a way that was not intended by the Creator. They watch for sheer entertainment. they want a traditional linear storyline, they want action, explosions and special effects. What makes this film so spectacular is how incredibly unique it is. No other film can be compared to it. The Fountain explores deep philosophical messages about life, death and love. The prospect of morality and how so many view it as a negative.

I have viewed the film twice now, and was able to appreciate it so very much more the second go around. The symbolic meanings placed throughout the entire film became ever clearer. Technically this film is also very strong. The acting is superb, the cinematography beautiful, the direction spot-on. The Fountain is a rare film that viewers will get more and more out of with each repetitive viewing.

More than anything I appreciate The Fountain, because of it's profound impact it has had on me. I left the theater of different person. My views on life, and everyday situations have changed. And as a student filmmaker it has truly inspired me.

Bottom line: This film is art, much like beautiful poetry.

title: Visual Poetry in Motion
review:
I'm not sure what the professional critics seem to have against this film. To me it seemed to be what David Lynch, The Wachoski's, and Tim Burton have all aspired to, and never quite reached. I'm fairly jaded and film weary, myself, but when something like THE FOUNTAIN comes along, it reminds me of why I keep going to the movies. This is the perfect sort of film to enter into without expectations...meet it on the filmmakers terms, and you won't be disappointed. In the films by the previously mentioned folks, I'd often leave with the sense that they were poking fun at the audience, or aware of the concept of deeper meaning, but simply unable to express it. They seem pretentious. Aronofsky, on the other hand, knows how to tell a story, and knows how to tell one that resonates with those who are prepared to listen.

This truly is a poem in film form. The use of interweaved layers of story and repetition of symbolism maintains a steady pace, which slowly builds to a truly climactic (when you look up "climax" in the dictionary, this film's could be the definition of the word) crescendo.

title: One of the Best films ever made
review:
It is rare in which a filmmaker presents us with a film that not only challenges our beliefs and feelings, but also how we look at film. Darren Aronofsky shows signs of becoming a filmmaker in the ranks of Stanley Kubrick. His films Pi and Requiem for a Dream showed us his prowess of presenting a relentless harrowing experience as if we were committed to the characters of the film. His films are about subtext, and they truly remember what too few directors realize today: film is an art form, not just a senseless montage of explosions and useless story lines (Michael Bay pay heed).

This film presented an experience of which I cannot compare. It speaks of transcendence for the sake of love. I heard a friend say that Aronofsky IS the next Kubrick, but only time will tell. The plain fact of the matter is this film is gorgeous from start to finish. The ending harrows that of 2001: A Space Oddesy in terms of pure innovation. Clint Mansell's beautiful score (brilliantly featuring heartfelt performances by both the Kronos Quartet and Mogwai) is the best I have heard this year. Matthew Libatique's cinematography is by far the best of the year. Very few times in my history of watching film and going to film festivals have I seen such beauty. There were many moments which I just stared at the screen literally in awe of the images I was presented with. I feel very torn on this film for one reason.

This year we have been presented with many fine films from established directors. The Departed, The Prestige, Babel, The Queen, Volver, and the Fountain are all beautiful in there own right. But it really comes down to only 2 of these films in true terms of best picture material. The Departed and The Fountain. The Departed despite being a remake of the amazing Hong Kong action film Infernal Affairs, establishes itself apart from its parent material by the performances contained within it and the re-imagining of the storyline. Scorsese is definitely in the running (in my opinion) for best director. While this film is brilliant, it shares the limelight (for anyone that is paying attention) with The Fountain. Hugh Jackman's performance single handedly keeps this film out of the gutter of artsy trash by showing you a man who is truly broken by his wife's predicament. Not only is this the single best performance by Jackman, it also ranks as one of the best of the year. Without this performance, the film quite simply would falter with anyone else in the role. On top of this fact is Aronofsky's directing ability. He handles his material with such love and tenderness for the sheer beauty of the medium of film. Too often in Hollywood directors are just trying to make a buck selling weak films that only establish itself on the scenes of violence or camera trickery they use.

Needless to say I personally recommend this film to anyone who is a true cinema lover. People who were raised correctly on the classics of film (1900-1970's). Not just flashy images from 1980-2000. The problem with this film for most American audiences is it is too high brow. It forces you to think and connect the pieces as to the man's fate (i.e. Goddard, Peckinpah, Lumet, Murnau, Hitchcock, Malick, and yes Kubrick), and not just accept what you are seeing. I witnessed many walkouts by the MTV generation used to the overstimulate nature of films today, and I pray that one day America can turn itself around and bring back true respect for celluloid.

See this film if you are ready to experience a film of passion and love for not only transcendental ideas, but also of the nature of film making itself.

Do not see this film if you have trouble with films like Baraka or Babel. I cannot state this enough that it is NOT a film for American movie going audiences, it is a film for filmmakers and lovers of cinema.

Never has a film affected me like this one. I sat stunned by it throughout the credits and couldn't talk about films for days afterward. Like 2001: A Space Oddesy, this film will be hated for ridiculous reasons, but by no means should critics get in the way of true film lovers.

title: One story three layers
review: Being a big fan of Pi and well, I don't know if you can say you "enjoyed" Requiem, but I was anxious to see this film for 2 years. I have never written a review of any kind, but reading the previous which compared this to Donnie Darko, I felt I had to say something. This is not a sci-fi movie, it is not a medievalesk sword battle. It is an art-house movie about someone dealing with death, with enough of the aforementioned cool stuff to keep it fun to watch. But in a nutshell, and trust me this is no spoiler, it is one man trying to save his wife through chemistry, her metaphorical story about his struggle trying to save her, and the lofty sci-fi internal metaphor of how he sees himself. Its a beautiful creation, I enjoyed it and felt awed at the accomplishment. But, to be clear its not action, it is not Pi and it is definitely not Donnie Darko. Its not even Solaris, but it does remind me of something Tarkovsky might enjoy.

title: More than meets the eye...
review:
I have to say that the reviews on this movie were less that inspiring. I can understand how most people would miss what this movie is about, mistaking it for a scattered love story across what seems an endless time line. It couldn't be anything further from that hopeless synopsis that i can imagine. This brilliant film is a depiction of our inner selves and the simple yet epic struggle of being present with ones self. Which can mean the difference in our experience hear on earth becoming heaven or hell. How beautiful that it is our choice.

I would like to further stipulate that this film does not take place over the course of thousands of years but that it happens within the essence of a sheer moment, the here and now, which is all there is. It begins with him telling his wife he couldn't spend the moment with her because he was to busy trying to save her life, and ends with his enlightened response to the same question.

I further maintain that the bubble in space represented his state of being or mind and was a visual manifestation of where his awareness was during the entire experience.

The story of the conquistador was his wife's method of showing her beloved husband what it means to truly live, forever, together. She used a method in which he could easily follow, as he wasn't ever really with HER, he was only consumed with the inner desire to hold on to the idea of her. As he was loosing her, he clung to the only thing that would make him feel consumed by her, an unfinished story which he was to write the end to. This took him down the path of ultimate enlightenment which is what you see at the very end of the film. Again people mistake this for some hocus pocus or loss of focus on account of the creators. This is his coming to the conclusion that life is eternal right here and now, that death is but a mere transformation, and that as we are beings of energy, that there really is no end, just endless evolution.

I also believe the creators of this story intended to bring up the point that we have people in our lives who guide us to higher awareness and understanding, and I believe his wife was his guide.

There is so much to this film I plan on seeing it a few times and I give it two thumbs up!!

title: Beautiful Movie
review: When my husband and I went to see this movie, I noticed that there were three different types of movie goers. First, were the people who plain didn't get it. They turned to their friends after the movie and said "Wait a minute, what was the deal with the guy and that tree?" and similarly annoying questions. Second, were the people who walked out. They didn't get either. The difference is that they were impatient, probably thinking something like "Ugh, this is so boring! When are they gonna blow something up?" At least they were nice enough to be quiet as they left. Then, there were the people like my husband and I. We may not have understood the movie perfectly (who can after only one viewing) but we were awestruck by the beauty and intelligence of this film. This is one of my favorite movies now (and believe you me, I am not one of those people who goes to see movies like Shop Girl and Little Miss Sunshine and calls herself enlightened and smarter than everyone else.) I am not going into what the movie is about because I want people who haven't seen this movie yet to be able to read this review and still go, see this film, and not have it ruined for them. Ignore all those people who call this movie "artsy, fartsy crap". They are entitled to their opinions just like everyone else. I think that you should see this film, not because I loved it and think that this movie will move you deeply (if you understand it) but because this movie should be given a fair chance. You will either love this movie, hate it, or just plain don't get it. It' worth it to go just on the chance that you may love it. I can't get this movie out of my head and I watched it a week ago. It's a beautifully made, thought provoking movie and you should see it. Please disregard everything you've heard about this movie (including this review), put your hands over your ears and sing "LA, LA, LA" at the top of your lungs if someone tries to tell you about it, and go watch it.

title: A wild and imaginative ride throughout the ages for the thinking a nd feeling film-goer.
review:
Darren Aronofsky will no doubt be regarded as one of the most creative, insightful and dedicated to his art directors of our generation. He has created a moving lyrical poetic film about life after death and one only hopes his growing thinking audience will embrace the film as his best yet.

True love comes through as soul mates throughout time and the images, which sometimes are disturbing are enlightening as well as to the nature of soul mates. Fantastic sensitive performances by the leads, Hugh Jackman and Rachel Weiss as well as notable roles for Ellen Burstyn as Hugh's boss and Mark Margolis as Father Avila. We need to see these two professionals in more films. The younger stars are wonderful compliments to the brooding and intense Jackman and balance him well.

Overall the picture came from darkness and death and moved to the light. I would like to see Darren Aronofsky lighten up his pallet in the future and cater to a broader audience. Thw world awaits you sir.

title: Portrait of the different sides of love
review:
When I say the different sides I don't mean the bad and good because love is by definition good. Instead there are three stories used to show how love is courageous, patient, and caring. The courageous heroic side of love is represented in a story of a conquistador. The patient contemplative side of love is shown in a futuristic setting. The caring side of love is demonstrated in modern times. Masterfully intertwined and used perfectly to evoke the emotions Aronofsky is trying to convey.

You may have a different interpretation but that's the best part about Aronofsky films. The emotions are clear but the interpretation, the thematic focus, is up to to the person watching.

The movie contains amazing sets, beautiful lighting, and a heart wrenching story. Don't look for the plot as much as the experience. The plot is fine but you'll miss more than half of the movie if that's what you focus on.

In order of favorite to least favorite Aronofsky films I would rate them: Requiem for a Dream, The Fountain, Pi

title: A haunting and profound experience
review: My partner and I saw The Fountain last night. One of our tests of whether a movie is good or not is if it 'wears' well. Some movies I forget as soon as I see them. Other movies bring up a bad taste in my mind when I remember them. Others come back to me in various ways days or weeks after seeing them. The Fountain was such an experience for me. All through the day I kept remembering bits of the movie: the tone, the mystery, the journey. I wanted to tell people about the movie. This is another good sign. I have not read any reviews of the film, nor have I talked w/ anyone who has seen it other than my partner. I can hear some people saying now: "It doesn't make any sense!" or "What was that bubble? Why was he floating?" These are the same kinds of people who are better off seeing one of the 'Ernest' movies, in which everything is spelled out in numbing detail. I prefer a movie that leaves questions in one's mind. I like to be involved in the unfolding of what is on screen. I don't generally like, or trust, a director who feels it is necessary to explain and underscore every single significant moment in a movie, nor one who feels it necessary to wrap everything up in a cute Dickensian bow. There are two things I liked most about The Fountain. One is its beautiful imagery and creative use of myth. The other is its emotional rawness. If anyone has ever faced losing a loved one, s/he will know just how desperately helpless one can feel. It is incredibly easy to believe anything in a state of denial. It is also tragically easy to miss the most important thing that is always in front of us: the present moment. There were times in the movie when I felt like it was too much --- I felt many times like I needed to stop the movie and go somewhere and sob for an hour. This is probably what I will do when I watch the movie at home when it comes out on DVD. This is not an easy movie to watch. But it is extremely rewarding, if you open the part of your mind that allows mystery to exist. I highly recommend it.

title: soo good
review:
this movie was beautiful...so glad Cate blanchett and brad Pitt opted out, it wouldn't have been as subtly gorgeous with those two garish actors stealing the screen. Hugh Jackman was amazing and Rachel weisz is a star...another masterpiece from the makers of pi and requiem.

i love that this story used fantasy--both past and future flashes--to tell this story. The result was like a triptych, whereby the fiction narrative of the past and the future served to express the feelings of despair, love, longing, death and acceptance that both characters felt in the present.

I also appreciated the special effects and all the beautiful symbolism of nebula, trees, flowers and rings...it was nothing short of amazing. This movie has something for everyone, as long as you open your mind to it.

title: Bewilderment...
review:
First off, I have to state that in order to explain this film, you have to see it yourself. it is almost impossible to write this review, for the film had so much wonder that left me and the audience bewildered and speechless. It is a highly unusually film that could be seen in many different views. That said, a lot of previous reviews of this film that I have read are quite different and off key, at least from the way I viewed the film.

To put this film in simpler terms, it is about the whole topic of death. Which includes spirituality, reincarnation, loads and loads of symbolism, specifically with trees, henceforth the tree of life, and also various time periods. The story is about a couple Tom Creo (Hugh Jackman) and Izzi Creo (rachel Weisz). It ends up that Izzy has cancer and is near death. Tom does everything in his power to stop her from dying.

meanwhile, back in the 1500s, the same two people are in the same circumstances, and Tom, known as the Conquistador is sent to South America to locate the Tree of Life. Both stories intertwine and bring together neatly and dramatically with surprising ends. both are great pieces to the story.

However, the third story is very confusing, which is the story 500 years from modern-day, and it is when Tom is an astronaut, who is bound to a tree that is dying, supposedly representing his ill wife. he travels in a bubble to a star that suppsoedly gives you rebirth and life.

This story, in my mind, pulled away and created diversions from the original two stories. It took a long time to explain what the story stood for, and it at least gave some explanation at the end of the film, which was no more than mere implications, which left me hanging saying "Okay, now what?" Another thing about the film was that the director used the same scenes throughout the film, as if to warn the audience, "okay, it's time for a new scene". This grew very annoying, and only slowed the pace of the film, making a 95 minute film feel an hour extra longer. These delays also caused some damage to the end, which was left hanging, instead of totally resolved. in other words, there was to be more of the film at the end, but was cut short, and left almost like a cliffhanger (previously stated earlier in the paragraph).

Besides these flaws, the film was great. The director uses a lot of up closes and different camera angles compared to the average Hollywood director. Rachel Weisz and Hugh Jackamn gave powerful performances, but neither of them were Oscar worthy. The visual effects were flat out amazing, and beyond the works of Lord of the Rings, not to mention the use of beautiful cinematography that gave a feel to the film, as well as other small details such as: costumes, set-decoration, and a moving music score by Clint Mansell.

It was a great film that was unfortunately flawed, but still held a strong lesson that tells us that we're all going to die someday, but it's what we do in our life that defines us.

*** out of **** Not the best thing, but a decent film

title: Mesmerizing
review:
To those who are affected by this film, its cerebral, meta-physical notions are pinned to a fine love story. Without being overly subjective, this movie is superbly crafted. I've rarely experienced a movie that compelled me to collect my thoughts during the credits.

Suggestion: Ensure you're in the mood to wrap you mind around the concepts and involve your heart in the story line, allowing for much post-film discussion.

The leads deliver excellent character portrayals that serve to further humanize the concepts and emotions. This is one for both the box office and home library.

title: a cerebral roller-coaster ride traversing paths of existence and love.
review: This movie spewed philosophical allusion wall to wall the entire 120 minutes. To set myself down softly here instead of crashing loudly into the proverbial wall of criticism too early on I'll say this: only see this movie if you come geared up to think. And I mean think. The cognitive spirit of the story was intersticed with a tale of endearing romance, a lifelong struggle, and the fraility of existence. The interprations of a tree of life to represent a riddle of the indifference of life was beyond words. It inspired me the way a flash of insight inspires a scholar to write ceaselessly until all thoughts are expounded. And to think that Arranofsky was capable of maintaining direction in this film which is primarily quiet, contemplative, and unlinear. Of course, The Fountain won't leave you with a cerebral aftertaste lying dank in your mouth. Instead it delivers a poignant tale of a romance so powerful it inspires a man to devote his entire being to saving his wife. The story and it's elaborate imaginatory content spans a thousand years. In one instance, the conquistador is searching for the fountain of youth in New Spain and in the other scene memories and thoughts occupy a future where beings transcend time and space in life pods. Ultimately, the overlying themes behind the Fountain are more than enough rationale to conclude this as a must-see. If not for intellectual inspiration, perhaps at least for its science fiction value.

title: Simply beautiful
review:
my interpretations: It's hard to digest the whole immensity of the movie after one viewing. The movie has been falsely advertised as being a story of undying love with three parallel stories when in fact this movie has only one true story and it isn't about love. The story is about one man's journey in accepting death as a part of natural order of the universe. Thomas the conquistador is merely a metaphor for the 21rst century Tommy's reckless pursuit on finding a cure for the degenerating disease his wife has. That metaphor is portrayed by the fictional tale Lizzy has written on her book. She intentionally leaves out the last few pages to be written by Tommy after her death so he can come to peace with the idea of immortality through the infinity and rebirth through death. The future Tom is an allegory for tommy's unwavering and unending quest in saving his dying wife while he himself is perishing slowly in his work, losing his humanity, losing perspective in what's truly important.

Therefore, out of the 3 stories, the 21rst century one is actually the only literal one. The past is tied with Lizzy's book and the future is tommy's internal struggle into coming at peace with her death.

The ending scene is beautiful, he plants a a seed on her grave so that she can be one with the cosmos and breed new life and render life through death.

well I could be totally wrong but those are my opinions.

title: Truly a masterpiece
review:
This film is just, wow. I've been waiting to see it for months and it reached more than my expectations. There's something about this movie that I just can't describe. The visuals are stunning, the actors are stunning, the style is stunning, the music is stunning, the story is amazing...

First you watch it and it's already an incredible experience, but a couple days later your mind will get disturbed. The movie is intense and unique in so many ways that you just can't capture the whole thing the first time you watch it. Many interpretations can be made about the real story and timeline of this movie. For this reason and many others, it will become a cult. I can't wait to watch it again from a different angle.

My advice : you can pay 10 bucks for your ticket, but a soul is priceless, and you need one to watch The Fountain.

Classic.

title: A great movie to make you think about your own life
review:
To start, I'm surprised to view so many negative comments (by critics) of this piece of art. Critics are always complaining about the non-artistic, flawed, action, sappy, movies that are 99% of what we all see in theaters, yet they bash such a profound, beautiful, and artistic film. Goes to show that this film is before its time. I wouldn't be surprised years ahead, once this film is revisited, it will get just a piece of the merit it deserves.

To continue, this movie is not for all to see and understand as some will not even get the message that is being projected in that 1hr and 1/2. This movie is not meant to just entertain but to re-examine what we all think about out own mortality. Some see movies as a form of entertainment and thats it, "Movies are just Movies". Yet "movies", at least the ones that fall into this category, are an art form that are meant to make you think and open your mind. Have you been to a museum and seen works of art? What type of mind set do you go with? These are the questions you have to view this movie with. Hugh Jackman is stupendous and should be considered for an Oscar! Hugh's acting is at his best and he really projects the emotion to the viewer about a man afraid to lose everything that he loves only to the inevitable death (the theme of the movie). The score is what it should be, a passionate piece! And every time you hear what I believe was the main song (Stay With Me), you can't help immersing yourself in Hugh Jackman's shoes every time its played, very heart-felt. Visually, one of the best films I have ever seen, and that is not an exaggeration if you know how to appreciate how cinematography works and how beautiful art can be.

To conclude, I know not all will like this film because mentally we all do not think the same. But those that read this, have seen the film with a positive light, and agree with this comment understand the potential to this artistic film. In plain English, this movie is about the struggle of a man's mortality and the threat we all feel when someone we love is on the brink to leave us to death. Yet death is not the end but the symbol to the "true eternal life". To those willing to view, open your minds, and to those not willing, I hope you reach that level.

title: Immortality means surrendering to death.
review:
This is not entertainment. This is cinema at its best. Weaving through exquisitely amazing images, Aronofsky talks about time as a structural dimension of consciousness; and death as a transitional stage in the continuous stream of life. It is a philosophical, existential, spiritual (if you like), and very much a humanistic film. Everything exist at the this moment: life, death, past, present, future, pain, pleasure, love, and loss.

More frequently than not, the critics disappoint me. Reading their reviews reminds of the intellect of a six-year old child. Watch the movie, let it sink in, and allow it to unfold in your daily life, gradually and repeatedly.

title: don't think, see
review: the concept betrays the perfunctory audience, the film industry itself was created to render a world of streamlined constituents and plot. aronofsky has produced a tapestry - it is a work of art and the first film i have seen in several years that goes about its own existence and self-awareness in a method of ambivalence. our cultural identity is long defined by books - their importance was contingent on our myriad explications. aronofsky makes no comments on what we should feel at the end of the fountain, it is an experience by itself and in that we are allowed to find our own meaning. i recommend this film to anyone who thought every last vestige of art had been perverted. there is hope. get your ticket and just take the painting in, just sit and ignore the whispers of less aware audience members, and see the intricacy and consciousness. the film has its flaws, but if you look at it on the macro level it is an impressive feat of craft.

title: Thought-Provoking
review: This film is a beautiful exploration of the enigmatic topic of death, love and life. Aronofsky's handling of the film's metaphysical subject matter is captured to great precision in its form. There are obvious homage's or allusions to Kubrick's "2001..." masterpiece as this film strays from rationality and neat 'cause and effect' formations. This was very appropriate considering the various questions the film poses rather than answers. To read the film on a literal narrative level is somewhat possible, but this misses the point of the film. Aronofsky is more concerned with experience than coming to conclusions. To offer rational explanations for some of the pro-filmic events does not pose justice to the film's creative sensibility. The film explores the boundaries of editing and linearity, which is not new for this director. It is not a carbon copy of prior works, but is more of a challenging engagement with the viewer in how we watch or experience cinema differently than any other artistic medium.

title: WOW great movie
review: I thought the movie was fantastic! I really don't have enough words to say about this amazing movie.Its one of those films that is so stunning and awe inspiring, you don't know how to frame it. It is true what someone else said that you have to have a certain mental capacity,and depth of understanding to really get and appreciate this movie. Yes, it was very ambitious, and sometimes hard to follow, but a wonderful statement on love,loss,the afterlife, and the meaning of it all. I must say that it is refreshing and wonderful to see that a movie like this one can even be made anymore considering the sad state of affairs of the industry and this culture in general. Just when I have given up hope of thinking that there was even people left out there that really GOT what truly is important in life. This film is a beautiful statement about what is. Stunning visuals,great acting, and a beautiful message is alone enough to see this movie. But go see it for your self before you make up your mind. Its one of those films that either you love or hate. and its funny that from what I have read its split about 50/50 on the reviews. It is one movie that stays with you for sure.

title: Just Amazing!
review: I love this movie, I was crying not only by the visuals, but because of the story. Along with the rest of Darran's films, this is the best. Fight Club used to be my favorite movie of all time and this has taken it's place! The issues about life and death are portrayed wonderfully in both. But as a movie The Fountain and Fight Club are on the same page in my mind. I loved the move also because it makes you think about everything in life. It isn't said or explained. You have to feel it. You have to interact with the story and be there vicariously and it will all fit in together. 10/10 from me and besides The Departed I hope this movie wins the best movie of the year!

title: A cinematic masterpiece
review: This Film is so amazing that it has a power of creativity so hard to put into words... The fountain contains so much of everything I personally long for in a movie. its amazing to be able to have seen the story about life and death. In a way its a lot like begging and end. Love and life. As a film its one of the best movies you can watch an a date. I will say only that the images you see are enhanced with the brilliant composer Clint mansell and hes score then you have an emotional undertone that thoughts itself at you without your permission you are left in. A complete ah. Its a wonderful experience I would recommend for anybody that has any interest in the medium of film-making.

title: Not only the best film of the year, but one of the best of all time.
review:
I just saw the new Darren Aronofski film, Th Fountain, yesterday and it completely blew me away. Clocking in at only an hour and a half, it makes every shot, every line absolutely count. The direction, acting and story are all flawless. The story is a non-linear tale of a man (Hugh Jackman) who seeks to defeat death in three separate time periods -- the Spanish Inquisition, modern American and an untold number of years into the future. Each frame is an absolute work of art and the performances are nothing short of amazing. It's also interesting to observe how Aronofski managed to construct a detachment from reality and humanity while at the same time preserving the deep, underlying emotions that undoubtedly connect the main character there. I would not be heartbroken if this film took every Oscar for 2006 (including best director.) I have literally racked my brains to come up with something wrong with this movie I seem to always come up with nothing. Warning: Don't watch this movie as you would a normal movie -- just let it take you along and watch for the connective theme that prevails in all three stories.

If you wanna see a really good movie, a movie that MATTERS, for God's sake, see the Fountain! Five Stars... one of the best movies I've ever seen!

title: Oh it's beautiful but, the story line ? Oh the story is intermangled.
review:
I agree with what this person said so I copied and put it here as my comment. Kinda like what most established Screenwriters do when Writers send in Treatments and Screenplays to an Agent who pawns it off to those established screenwriter's. Yeah, their best ideas get extracted and used in someone else's work:

"the plot structure wasn't as cohesive as it could've been. the intermingling of time dimensions is nothing new, however for this movie it was abit jumpy and required the audience more effort in deciphering it's flow rather than enjoying a good story. The visuals were stunning awesome but didn't lend any true significance to the storyline. as a special effect it's cool, but there was no solid relevance to the story. for instance, with bullet-time and frame freezing there is relevance with what is going on in the scene and how it works as a function of the movies story and plot. Whereas in "Fountain" all you get is beautiful imagery with music that doesn't particularly drive the story forward. It's non-functional imagery. But that's okay, I enjoyed it. However for a movie, no, I can see where this sound and imagery would be really cool with some fine Columbian Gold and a water bong ! 3 stories, 3 time dimension, is a worn out idea. however it works for this "movie" sort of.

When I watched it( 4 hours ago ) I caught the Holiday Season crowd, so a lot of people were already giddy. Wolverine was easier chuckled at or hissed at depending on what type of emotion he was trying to evoke. I thought he was doing well since I didn't get to see the last X-men movie. People still look at him as Wolverine so that kinda ruined it for them. Rachel was immaculate in her acting, and if it wasn't for her, the movie wouldn't have much substance. I mean her acting was excellent. Some of the visuals made no sense and were quite distracting. It's almost as if the Director has all these fantastic ideas in front of him and didn't know what to do, so he just through them all together with no concern as to how they'd make sense.

The movie is better viewed as an Art piece like most viewers have already said. So, this is not a movie in the traditional sense, but tries to be one. Actually, I was bored and thought the visuals provided some thought provocation, the story line was not cohesive enough to drive any meaningful point that I already couldn't decipher from a few lines of dialog or a still image.

I figure the screenwriter needed more time with the content. this movie had so much potential but it seemed thrown together without any refining. And, indeed, it needs a lot of refining to be considered seriously. therefore, I conclude that "the fountain" is no "The Matrix" but it was a good try for the Director in trying to do something different. " - someone else's words.

Thank you, JQ

title: Neither Loved nor Hated
review:
I went to see this yesterday as part of the Vancouver International Film Festival, and walked out knowing I would need some time to think before talking.

The three people I was with instantly disliked the movie, and saw it as a waste of time, which surprised me since they were fans of his other movies. However, I can appreciate where they were coming from. The movie can be a bit of a cluster-%#^! at times. Nothing is handed to the viewer in this movie - it's up to the individual to get something out of it. Which I think I did, or at least I'm still doing.

So if you're in the mood to let your brain and ideas of mortality be tested, go see this movie. However, if you'd rather be force-fed a storyline (and I don't blame you if you do), go elsewhere.

title: The story seems original, but if you look closer, you can see that it is cliché and its visuals are no more than a slide show
review: The Fountain seems like a different film, it is a combination of past, present and future with different settings and stories. It is a hybrid movie, it has science fiction elements, it is a drama about a doctor and his ill wife, it is epic, there are Mad Max- like punk? tribes, it is a postmodern film, but none of those makes The Fountain a good film. The present story is the main story, it is the starting point, but this main story is very cliché that we saw even in some B movies! A doctor's wife is sick. He uses science to try to cure his wife who he loves. That's the story of the film. What a simple story! The worse thing is that this story doesn't go any further and we can't feel the romance or the pain either. Other than this, yes, as some other audiences said, the movie is extremely pretentious. The images, all those visual elements doesn't make any sense, instead it was like a long and very boring slide show. As a moviegoer, I very rarely call a movie boring, but The Fountain just pushed my limits. The images, some of those were beautiful, yes, but it is like all those images has not any supportive or enough background or emotion. It is called pretentious, right? This is not style over substance stuff, because there is not any real story for this feature length film, there are rather some ideas. I said the man who tries to save his wife is the brief story of the film, but it is more like a sum of ideas rather than a real, interesting story. Hugh Jackman doesn't fit his role, also he was not very good in this, Rachel Weisz was more adaptable than him, but both of them were literally missing in the movie. It seems that even they didn't believe the story, the movie. This film proves that all of the different time zones, different stories films are not good, just because it sounds or looks different. If you liked Moon, you will like The Fountain, there is no doubt about it! I couldn't like Moon either, because it was the same as The Fountain. No heart and soul. The Fountain has no heart and soul, no dramatic scene or twist. The movie's pseudo weightiness was over for me. This isn't high art for me, this isn't entertainment, this isn't a cinematic journey, this is something else, but I am sure about one thing, it was a zest-less experience.

title: Dull and boring
review: The dramatic visuals were impressive, watching Hugh Jackman fly through space in his little tree garden was pretty spectacular in a big screen cinema. Unfortunately the fine visuals were ruined by what is a very slow moving film. Considering the length of the film I would expect a little more too happen. Although maybe it just felt like a really long movie. Some may like the spiritual aspects. I didn't. A movie can make you think without boring you to tears. In the end, I couldn't wait for the film to end. Watching a guy eat a tree in the middle of space is not my idea of an entertaining movie. I recommend that this movie only be watched with mates, whilst chatting and consuming alcohol.

title: Not sure if it was a fountain of water :D
review:
I don't know why "great" directors try to make pretentious, extra- ordinary and space-related movies to show that they are open-minded , philosopher and in a simple word "great. I didn't like the movie just like Interstellar or 2001. Cliché surrounded the whole plot and I just couldn't sympathy with any of characters. I prefer the death of Sponge Bob Squarepants's Hamburger than of Izzy.

When I "finished it" , I just realized there is nothing changed in my mind, except the so-called artistic-scientific idea of "Death leads to a new life." As one of the commentators said, I just couldn't stop laughing when the plant grew on his belly. :D

Anyway, I wasted my time watching movie and then leaving this comment. :)

title: Warner Bros. Bad Trip
review:
All I could think of throughout the movie was how W-B ever recouped their investment in this stinker. At first I thought you had to be high to watch this, then I realized you had to have been even higher to pitch the movie.

What this movie was was an exercise in special effects. I think I quit counting after a half dozen different special effect companies flashed across the screen credits.

Hugh Jackman's a talented guy, but between The Fountain and Van Helsing, he's committing artistic suicide.

This is one of those "See it on cable" movies. I feel sorry for anyone who actually went to a theater to see it or spent good money on the DVD. There's a reason I never heard of the movie until March of 2008. Warner Bros. probably sent The Fountain direct to DVD.

Bad trip all the way around.

title: The Fountain She Studied Science in Junior High School **1/2
review:
Hugh Jackman and Rachel Weisz are well cast in this film. Their acting is quite good but in reality, what are they really trying to achieve here?

The film has its good moments when it is up-to-date with a dedicated doctor desperately trying to save his wife from a fatal brain tumor.
